title: hs2 betrayal 13 times decade
story: HS betrayal:  times in a decade the Tories broke rail promises to the NorthThe HS rail route to Leeds has been scrapped while Northern Powerhouse Rail has been downgraded. Yet Boris Johnson claims it’s “total rubbish” to say promises have been broken. We show why that’s flagrantly untrueBoris Johnson onboard a train from Wolverhampton to Coventry yesterday - after he had his rail plans sent to Coventry as well Image: Getty ImagesByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Nov We’ve had four Tory-led governments since , and all of them have made bold claims about rail to the North.But yesterday Boris Johnson shattered those pledges, scrapping a key part of HS and downgrading Northern Powerhouse Rail. The HS eastern leg will no longer run to Leeds while only a section of NPR will be new high-speed track, from Warrington to Marsden. And hopes of high-speed stations in Bradford and, once upon a time, Sheffield have all been ditched. Labour said the Tories have “recommitted and re-promised” a northern rail revolution  times since . And Keir Starmer said voters are starting to “see the Prime Minister for what he really is,” adding: “He’s a Prime Minister who thinks he can make promises and then break them and there’ll be no consequences.” Sure enough, Boris Johnson is trying to convince voters he’s an honest Joe - claiming it’s “total rubbish” to say he’s broken his promises. Transport Secretary Grant Shapps took it even further today, bizarrely moaning that complaints are from “largely Labour leaders who are completely misleading people”. This is, of course, not true - Tory MP for Keighley Robbie Moore said the plan completely short-changed his constituents while Tory MP Sir Edward Leigh said: “It’s a white elephant missing a leg”. And Conservative chairman of the Commons Transport Committee, Huw Merriman, put the focus on broken promises saying: This is the danger in selling perpetual sunlight and leaving the others to explain the arrival of moonlight.”  So what exactly did the Tories promise on HS and NPR  Here are  of the most egregious examples of pledges that have since been smashed.  October : Tory ministers propose a Y-shaped HS line via Birmingham to Manchester in the West and Leeds in the East. In the East, the line would stop in Sheffield Meadowhall and there would be a high-speed linking line to York. Phase One to Birmingham is set to open in , with Phase Two in  on an initial £.bn budget. The reality now: No HS stops in Leeds or Sheffield Phase One is now scheduled for “around ” and the surviving legs to Manchester and East Midlands Parkway are scheduled for the “early to mid s”.  October : PM David Cameron and George Osborne give their backing to ‘HS’ - “a high speed rail link connecting the north’s great cities which could signicantly reduce journey times across the region”. This later is named Northern Powerhouse Rail, linking Manchester to Leeds and possibly going further. The reality now: There will be no high-speed intercity link in NPR, only a high-speed section between Warrington, Manchester, and Marsden. The majority of NPR will be on upgraded existing track, saving £bn.  November : Transport Secretary Patrick McLoughlin declares: “We are already looking at HS. An east-west line joining up the great cities of the north. From Liverpool to Hull.” The reality now: Northern Powerhouse Rail is mostly not high-speed track, and will not run to Hull - it will stop in York. June : After David Cameron wins a majority, Transport Secretary Patrick McLoughlin goes to Leeds and says: “The argument has been won. HS will be built, the full ‘Y’ network, from London to Birmingham and Birmingham to Manchester and Leeds, with construction starting in just  years.” The reality now: There will be no leg to Leeds. Construction on the eastern leg to East Midlands Parkway will only begin in the late s. November : The government unveils updated HS plans. They will still build a Y-shaped line, including the Eastern leg to Leeds - although Sheffield will be left off the proposed route, sparking fury. A document says “HS will have a transformational effect on journey times, with journeys between Leeds and Birmingham taking just  minutes, compared to  hour  minutes currently, and between Leeds and London taking  hour  minutes.” The reality now: Leeds leg has been dropped and the plan is for Leeds-Birmingham to take  hour  minutes and Leeds-London to take  hour  minutes.  April : After taking over from David Cameron as PM, Theresa May announces: “We remain absolutely committed to HS. It is a very important infrastructure project for the country. It is important that we increase capacity on this mainline and I believe that HS is the right way to do that.” The reality now: HS has been cut back and capacity to Leeds will be hit as a result. January : Transport Secretary Chris Grayling says: “We must keep on making the strategic case for HS and work hard to win over the public about its potential benefits. Let me reiterate. We are committed to a second stage between the West Midlands and Leeds and between Crewe and Manchester, completing the ‘Y axis’.” The reality now: The Y axis will not be complete. July : Boris Johnson takes over from Theresa May after triumphing with Tory members. He says days after entering office: “I want to be the Prime Minister who does with Northern Powerhouse Rail what we did for Crossrail in London. And today I am going to deliver on my commitment to that vision with a pledge to fund the Leeds to Manchester route.” The reality now: There will be a Leeds to Manchester route but only about half of it will be on high-speed track. December : The Tories win a manesto based on the pledge: We will build Northern Powerhouse Rail between Leeds and Manchester and then focus on Liverpool, Tees Valley, Hull, Sheffield and Newcastle.” It’s notable that the manesto does not pledge HS in full, instead promising to review the line. The reality now: While Tories insist they are building NPR it is not the high-speed line they envisaged. Birmingham to Newcastle will take  minutes longer than originally planned.  February : Boris Johnson says HS has green light despite doubts. While he only commits to the line extending as far as Birmingham, with further lines to Manchester and Leeds up for review, he adds: “This is about finally making a rapid connection from the West Midlands to the northern powerhouse - to Liverpool, Manchester and Leeds - and simultaneously permitting us to go forward with northern powerhouse rail across the Pennines, finally giving the home of the railways the fast connections they need. None of that makes any sense without HS.” The reality now: HS will only link up to NPR in Manchester, not in Leeds. February : Transport Minister Andrew Stephenson promises NPR will be a “new rail link”. He says: “We need to build new capacity. New rail links north to south, and east to west. That’s why we’re going ahead with both HS and Northern Powerhouse Rail. These are not ‘either or’ projects. They are both crucial to our future prosperity.” The reality now: NPR will mostly run on existing track, not be a new link.  February : Despite raising doubts over HS plans and ordering a review, Boris Johnson tells the Commons: “I can certainly confirm that we are going to develop the eastern leg as well as the whole of HS.” By now the expected budget has soared beyond £bn. The reality now: The government as done the exact opposite of what the PM promised. May : Transport Secretary Grant Shapps promises full-fat HS but perhaps a semi-skimmed NPR: We are going to complete HS and include HS on the eastern leg to Leeds. The only question that we have is how to better integrate that with plans which have developed a very long way since HS was first dreamt up all those decades ago. That particularly pertains to the northern powerhouse rail. The reality now: Both HS AND NPR have been downgraded.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Patrick McLoughlinTheresa MayGrant ShappsBoris JohnsonDavid CameronGeorge OsborneChris GraylingEdward LeighLabour PartyConservative PartyRailwaysPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news politics jenner-accuri-hand-over-boris-"Jenner Arcuri: People knew Boris Johnson had a crush on meByGeraldine ScottMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments Jenner Arcuri will hand over her diaries to investigators in a move which could prompt a fresh probe into Boris Johnson aposs links to the American businesswoman, it has been reported.The monitoring officer at the Greater London Authoritywill inspect parts of her diaries which detailed her relationship with the Prime Minister while he was mayor of London, The Observer reports.Her links with the Tory leader came under public scrutiny last year over allegations she received favourable treatment for her business ventures during his eight-year stint as mayor. Ms Arcuri alleged earlier this year in the Sunday Mirror that she and the PM had a four-year romantic relationship when he was mayor. In March she claimed they first slept together hours before he sat between his then-we Marina and Princess Anne at the opening of the  London Paralympics.She says they met up once a week at the height of the affair, and she sent him arty topless picture s. She admited: “I loved him. I adored him.”But she describes him as a “cowardly wet noodle” for not standing by her in the row over her presence on foreign trade trips. Mr Johnson avoided a criminal investigation after the police watchdog found no evidence he had influenced the payment of thousands of pounds of public money to Ms Arcuri, or secured her participation in foreign trade trips that he led.  However, the Independent Office for Police Conduct said it would have been wise for the former mayor to have declared their close association as a conflict of interest. The GLAaposs oversight committee is investigating whether he conducted himself in a way that is expected of people in public office. The Observer reported that Ms Arcuri has now agreed to be interviewed for the first time, and share notes she made in her diaries of their telephone calls and conversations.  A government spokesman told the Observer last week: As mayor, Boris Johnson followed all the legal requirements in the Greater London Authorityaposs code of conduct at the time. The GLA confirmed to the PA news agency it had received a complaint from Labouraposs deputy leader Angela Rayner, after some of Ms Arcuriaposs diary extracts were published by the newspaper last week. A spokesman said: The GLAaposs monitoring officer has received a complaint from Angela Rayner MP relating to the conduct of Boris Johnsonand has recorded it in line with the GLAaposs procedures. Recording a complaint does not mean that there has been any assessment or consideration of the merits of the complaint or that the complaint has any substance at this stage of the process.  The monitoring officer is seeking further information in order to assess the complaint. The Observer reported that Ms Arcuri told the GLA: I am prepared to show you or your investigators copies of the relevant pages. Mr Johnson has previously said his dealings with Ms Arcuri were done with complete propriety and previously welcomed the IOPC findings, as he criticised the vexatious claims against him. Previously, Mr Johnsonaposs press secretary said there was no case to answer following the findings by the IOPC. This work has been done - public time, money and effort has been spent looking into whether or not thereaposs any wrongdoing and it was found that the Prime Minister, the then London mayor, has no case to answer, she said. The GLAaposs monitoring officer will now review the complaint to see whether it is a serious complaint, and therefore whether it can be referred back to the IOPC. Ms Rayner tweeted: If Boris Johnson made promises of support to Jenner Arcuri because of his personal relationship with Ms Arcuri it is vital that the GLA refers this new evidence to the IOPC and that the IOPC reviews its decision to rule out a criminal investigation. We need a full investigation into whether the processes behind the public funding for Ms Arcuriaposs business and her presence on publicly-funded trade visits was the result of misconduct in public office by Boris Johnson. Comment MORE ON Boris JohnsonLabour PartyGreater London AuthorityConservative PartyPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: lobbying firms hand almost 2m
story: Exclusive: Lobbying firms hand almost £m to political parties - including a cabinet ministerAs well as paying MPs as advisors, analysis found least  firms listed on the official lobbying register, or their directors, have donated to political parties or MPs since the register was set up in Northern Ireland Secretary Brandon Lewis Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsLobbying firms have handed almost two million pounds to political parties and MPs - including a cabinet minister - the Sunday Mirror can reveal. As well as paying MPs as advisors, analysis found least  firms listed on the official lobbying register, or their directors, have donated to political parties or MPs since the register was set up in . They include Northern Ireland Secretary Brandon Lewis, who has accepted £, from lobbying firm Avre Partnership. In total, Avre and its directors have handed almost £, to the Tories and Tory MPs. The official register lists as their only client tech firm CityFibre, which is among the firms bidding to upgrade the UK’s broadband infrastructure. The Lib Dems received the most inidual party, with £, - although the majority of it is from party donors who also sit on the board of anti-Brexit campaign group Best For Britain. The Conservative Party accepted £, in cash and sponsorship, with Labour accepting £,. The total figure for all parties amounts to £. million since . The figures do not include the cost of staff lent to political parties by accountancy giants including KPMG, Pricewaterhousecoopers and Deloitte - which amounts to hundreds of thousands of pounds more in non-cash donations to parties.Sunday Mirror analysis compared data from the Register of Consultant Lobbyists, Companies House and the Electoral Commission to establish which firms and directors had been bankrolling political parties. Of the firms on the register, the largest donors to the Conservative Party were linked to CT Solutions and Private Advisory - the PR giant founded by Australian spin doctor Lynton Crosby.  Between the firm itself and director Mark Fulbrook, the Tories accepted £, in donations from  to . Conservative Party co-chair Ben Elliot, gave £, to the party while he was a director of London lobbying firm Hawthorne Advisory. In total,  separate firms and their directors handed cash to the Tories, compared to eight for Labour and four for the Lib Dems. All the donations were within the rules and properly declared. There’s no suggestion of any wrongdoing by the companies, parties or MPs. A spokesperson for Brandon Lewis said: All Brandon’s donations are fully, transparently declared and are in line with the rules.” A Conservative Party spokesperson said: “Donations to the Conservative party are properly and transparently declared to the Electoral Commission, published by them, and comply fully with the law.”  Boris Johnson was shamed into backing moves to crack down on MPs second jobs last week, after the scale of politicians accepting cash for “advisory” jobs was laid bare. But instead of backing Keir Starmer ’s plan, which would have banned most second jobs, Tories voted through watered-down measures which would only affect a handful of MPs.It followed Mr Johnson’s botched attempt to save disgraced former MP Owen Paterson from a -day suspension over his paid lobbying of ministers and officials on behalf of private firms. Speaking after the vote, Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer told broadcasters: We put forward a plan of action to clean up politics and strengthen standards in politics. Andyou can believe it, after two weeks of Tory sleaze and corruption, the Prime Minister whipped his MPs against that plan of action, and, frankly, he just doesnapost get it. title: priti patel set oversee more
story: Priti Patel set to oversee more small-boat crossings than she has voters in her seatShadow Home Secretary Nick Thomas-Symonds branded the Home Secretary’s failure to prevent the huge numbers risking their lives to cross the English Channel as a “dangerous and le threatening situation” for those making the journey Image: PAByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Nov | comments Priti Patel is set to oversee more small-boat Channel crossings than there are voters in her constituency, Labour has said.Labour Analysis found thatthe number of people crossing the Channel remains consistent with this year, the total would be more than , next year. Thataposs more than the number of electors in the Home Secretaryaposs constituency of Witham, which has , voters. The partyaposs number-crunching showed a % increase in the number of people crossing the channel over the last year. Each year since , the number of migrants making the perilous crossing across the Channel in small boats has multiplied. From  in , to , in , to , in  and more than , have arrived this year, almost triple last year’s tally. Labour’s Shadow Home Secretary, Nick Thomas Symonds MP, condemned the Home Secretary and the Prime Minister’s silence on the English Channel crossings as “inexcusable and reckless.” And branded the Home Secretary’s failure to prevent the huge numbers risking their lives to cross the English Channel as a “dangerous and le threatening situation” for those making the journey as well as a “broken promise to the British people”.  Boris Johnson has ordered a cross-government review into the migrant crisis as he is exasperated by a failure to stem the number of crossings from France, The Times reported on Saturday.But Mr Thomas-Symonds called on the PM to go further, and agree to a Channel crossings taskforce to meet weekly until the crisis is under control. He demanded on Ms Patel formally begin negotiations on new asylum regulations, publishing plans and timescales for the negotiation– with clear deadlines to prevent yet another winter of record channel crossings. And he said Ministers must prioritise the creation of properly managed safe and legal routes to help to prevent people from using people-trafficking routes and risking their lives on the English Channel – including the reintroduction of the Dubs Scheme for unaccompanied children. Mr Thomas-Symonds told the Mirror: “More and more people are risking their lives in the world’s most dangerous sea lanes in the English Channel. “After promising to address this, the Home Secretary has been completely absent and has lost control. In her two years as Home Secretary, far from the situation improving, we’ve seen an unprecedented % increase in numbers making the journey. “The Home Secretary has not only failed to end the dangerous and le threatening situation on the channel but also broken her promise to the British people to sort out the crisis on our borders. “It’s clear that the Home Secretary cannot be trusted in this issue and that urgent action is needed.”  Ms Patel has blamed the EUaposs open borders - established by the Schengen Agreement - for failing to check the movement of people through the bloc. Speaking to reporters during a visit to Washington, she said she was constantly pressing the French on the issue but that they were overwhelmed. Letaposs not forget that the real problem on illegal migration flows is the EU has no border protections whatsoever - Schengen open borders, she was quoted as saying. More than , people have arrived in the UK so far this year after making the Channel crossing in small boats - almost three times the number there were in . This includes at least , who arrived since Monday, according to data compiled by the PA news agency. This number is set to rise as the exact figure for Tuesday is still being finalised by the Home Office. It is thought at least  migrants have died in the last few weeks while trying to make the dangerous crossing. It comes as campaigners threatened the Home Secretary with legal action over so-called pushbacks after reports she had sanctioned the tactics to turn migrants around back towards France at sea. Meanwhile, French President Emmanuel Macron is reported to have said the British oscillate between partnership and provocation when discussing the migrant crisis in an interview with Lille-based newspaper la Voix du Nord, adding: We need to further strengthen collaboration. Officials have described how violence levelled at French police has intensied recently, highlighting incidents where an officer had their ear bitten off, and another where cannisters of CS gas had to be used to disperse a group of migrants. Sir Keir linked the increase to Government cuts in Britainaposs foreign aid budget as well as its failure to get a better agreement with France.We have not had strong enough agreements with France on this and we havenapost done the work upstream, he told the BBC Radio  Today programme.One of the reasons many Tory MPs were unhappy with the Government for cutting its foreign aid budget is because they knew that budget is used, in part, to deal with some of the problems that are driving the movement of people. You will never solve the immediate problemyou donapost solve the upstream problem. The Home Secretary repeatedly says in strong language what she is going to do about the immediate problem and delivers absolutely nothing. You have got to do the work upstream otherwise you will never solve this problem. Downing Street said the Government was continuing to work extremely closely with the French authorities on the issue, but that the problem required a co-ordinated response from countries across Europe. We are facing a global migration crisis choreographed by organised crime groups who put people on these boats to make these incredibly dangerous crossings, a No  spokesman said. This is an urgent issue for the whole of Europe, requiring incredibly close working together with our neighbours - France, Belgium and the Netherlands - as well as our friends across the continent. It is a shared problem so we need shared solutions. Sir Keir said the Government also had only itself to blame for the failings in Britainaposs busted asylum system. Ms Patel complained earlier this week that a dysal system had allowed Liverpool bomber Emad Al Swealmeen to remain in the UK despite reportedly having had an asylum application rejected in . Sir Keir said: My jaw dropped when I heard the Home Secretary say that the problem is that the asylum system is busted. This Government has been in power for  years. If the asylum system is busted it is busted under their watch. Asylum applications used to be dealt with in about six months many years ago. It now takes years. All of us MPs have constituents who have been waiting two years or more for their case even to be looked at. Sothe asylum system is busted the question is who busted it and the answer is the Government. news politics test-trace-set-scrapheap-thousands-"Nick Ferrari grills Robert Jenrick on Test and Trace failuresByJohn Siddle:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe £billion Test and Trace scheme is already being dismantled – despite fears of a devastating winter Covid crisis. A leaked dossier has laid bare plans to axe the shambolic system in . But a major step in winding it down will come next week. The Sunday Mirror understands the contact tracing system run by Sitel and Serco will be wound up early over crippling costs. Up to , contact tracers and call handlers were last week told their jobs were being axed, insiders said. In briefings by managers, teams were told there was “no money left”. Changes to the way tracing is done and more use of technology means jobs will be lost. And although Serco refused to comment, sources say they will not renew their contract when it expires on November . The Government’s plan is contained in a -page Whitehall dossier codenamed Operation Rampdown.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter The document details how Test and Trace will be ditched and the requirement for those exposed to Covid to self-isolate for  days will end. It comes despite the UK recording more than , new Covid cases on consecutive days last week. With a deadly fourth Covid wave sweeping Europe, experts fear the Government has made the wrong choice. Independent Sage’s Professor Susan Michie, a behavioural scientist, warned: “If we want to avoid the kind of lockdowns we are seeing in mainland Europe we need to step up our efforts in managing the pandemic and not start shutting them down. “The World Health Organisation says a working test, trace and isolate system is a cornerstone of pandemic management. Unfortunately the model which the Government pursued has been eye-wateringly expensive and not as effective as it should have been. “The model is broken, the model was never the correct one... and it has been evident all along.  “Transmission rates are still high – there are more than , new cases a day and , deaths a week. It is not a situation a country like ours should be accepting or happy to live with.” Currently, those who self-isolate are supposed to be contacted by Test and Trace workers to check they are complying with the rules. Unvaccinated travellers who arrive in the UK may also no longer be contacted. A White hall insider said: “The trough has run dry and the Treasury isn’t prepared to keep feeding the beast. The problem is, however, that cases are still re and winter is yet to begin. “For all its faults, it’s a dangerous game to sack contact tracers when the pandemic is still raging. You only have to look to Europe to see how things change. This is going to cause problems tracking iants or even keeping an eye on local outbreaks.” Test and Trace was set up in May  with a £billion budget.This year the programme – heralded as “world-beating” by PM Boris Johnson – received another £billion. The total is equivalent to a fth of the entire annual NHS budget.The Tories were slated for outsourcing Test and Trace, with , consultants paid a typical £, per day.  Covid call centres, meanwhile, were staffed by minimum-wage workers on two-week rolling contracts. All NHS Test and Trace Covid testing sites in England began closing at pm from this month in a bid to start saving cash. But Covid cases have doubled four times since June. And the Independent Sage  warned that “a further doubling would put tremendous pressure on our health service”. The system has also come under fire from education bosses. Last week it emerged that the Government had been unable to say how many contacts of Covid cases have been traced in schools since the start of the new academic year. This comes as latest figures show that Covid cases are rising once again among pupils, amid warnings from heads about the importance of contact tracing. The Department of Health and Social Care said it did not have data on the number of people who had been identied and contacted as Covid contacts in a school. The UK Health Security Agency said: “ Contact tracing remains a vital part of reducing Covid- transmission and therefore of our current NHS Test  Trace service. “If you are told to isolate by NHS Test  Trace it is essential that you do, unless exempt. We are constantly looking to make the tracing service as responsive, efficient and effective as possible.” Comment MORE ON Boris JohnsonNHSThe TreasuryWorld Health OrganisationPoliticsCoronavirusSunday Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: we need leader who shows
story: We need a leader who shows us the right thing to do and instead we have Boris JohnsonA new study this week showed wearing a mask reduces incidences of Covid by %. So it’s the right thing to do for all of us. But especially the right thing to do for the Prime Minister.Boris Johnson has been slammed for failing to wear a mask on public transport - which is against Government guidanceopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Nov | commentsThe Prime Minister said: “People have actually seen me wearing face coverings quite a bit more regularly as we have seen the numbers ticking up in the UK. “I think that is the responsible thing to do and I am going to continue to do it.” Great quote. Great sentiment. Responsible leadership at last. That was only a few days ago. But guess what happened next  That’s right. Mr Johnson was snapped on a northern train – more of this in a second – maskless. Bare-faced. Unfettered. It’s impossible to keep track of how many times our Prime Minister says something then does something . This pandemic is still raging. Cases are high. Winter is coming. We need to be on our guard. We need a leader we can look towards who shows us the right thing to do. Instead, we have Boris Johnson. Of course wearing a mask is not ideal. It’s not pleasant. It’s hot and stuffy and a nuisance. But it’s the right thing to do. You don’t have to wear one on every form of public transport – it’s not a legal requirement. But it’s the right thing to do. You know what the single most effective public health measure against the virus is  Go on, have a guess. Masks. A new study this week showed wearing a mask reduces incidences of Covid by %. So it’s the right thing to do for all of us. But especially the right thing to do for the Prime Minister. It just keeps happening. Even his apology this week sounded insincere – the giggling of a naughty schoolboy rather than a man who admits he’s wrong and vows to do better. He’d been caught without a mask at a hospital in the North East, not too far from where his friend went for an eye test. Mr Johnson said: “As for not wearing a mask in Hexham Hospital, which you wrap up into my general litany of crime, can I just say...” It’s not a serious remark. But this is not a serious man. For Mr Johnson to be caught out again is not really a surprise. But probably the most frustrating, exhausting, disappointing thing about this latest effort is where it took place. A train. A train in the north of England. A train running on a network that Mr Johnson and his Government promised to upgrade. We told you weeks ago he wasn’t going to do it, that he would let down the north and go back on his word. Sometimes, it is horrible being right. At least one good thing about this is that it means another blow to Mr Johnson’s credibility. His approval ratings are beginning to slide, the poll lead is shaky, and an election not the foregone conclusion it once was. Mr Johnson’s true character is emerging, revealing a lightweight figure not up to the task. The good times are over and the mask, as it were, has finally slipped. title: we should grateful mps give
story: We should be grateful MPs give up  minutes a year to ensure poor stay happyWe all know Members of Parliament find it hard to get by on a measly £, a year - no wonder they all want second jobs to keep them goingGeoffrey Cox Image: AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByMark Steel:,  Nov | commentsAt last it seems that some politicians feel a tinge of regret for spending their time on other jobs to bring in extra money, rather than concentrating on their main one. So Geoffrey Cox will make a heartfelt apology to the law firm that pays him over £, an hour – for nipping off to do  minutes a year in his second job as an MP. The MP Julian Smith will declare: “It has been a deep honour to earn £, for a few hours work advising energy companies. I am deeply sorry that I neglected my duties to them, by popping off occasionally to earn extra cash by moonlighting as an MP.” Some Tory MPs suggested it can be “really grim” to live on the MPs’ salary of £,. This is why they’re forced into taking second jobs. So I’m sure they’d approve of a change in the law, so anyone earning £, or less would be allowed to work somewhere  while still being paid for the first job that they don’t turn up to.  If you work in Morrisons, you’ll be allowed to spend all week advising an investment bank, then nip to the checkout for  minutes a month to charge someone for three tins of baked beans. Then you can put in for a few thousand pounds’ worth of expenses, for essential items such as a flamingo cleaner and a submarine. Tory MP Andrew Rosindell insisted we should be “cautious” before criticising MPs who can’t live on £, as we shouldn’t expect them to change their lestyle and remember that they’re human beings. He was just as sensitive when he supported cutting Universal Credit, saying claimants often “didn’t need the money, they just like the extra £”. It’s touching how he wants to also protect the lestyle of people with no money. If they clean offices all day for £ an hour, then take their kids to a foodbank, an extra £ would disrupt that lestyle. So Andrew goes out of his way to safeguard it, because he cares. There have been suggestions that working mothers who need more money should take on second jobs. They could grab a colander and stand at the end of a sewage pipe catching the turds before they float into the sea. Or they could charge £ a day to be a bouncy castle for Jacob Rees-Mogg’s children at a birthday party. Environment Secretary George Eustice actually said that working mothers who are struggling for money, could “work in abattoirs” for extra cash. This is the trouble with struggling working mothers – too few of them are prepared to make ends meet by strangling a pig. This would also solve the problem of lazy pigs who live off handouts of swill, rather than get off their trotters and do an honest day’s work like Peppa Pig and Miss Piggy and Pinky and Perky. So we should be grateful that our hard-working MPs do at least give up  minutes a year of their time, to go into Parliament, and vote to ensure the poor stay happy by being even poorer. title: army veteran takes life after
story: Exclusive: Army veteran takes own le after PTSD therapy axed as grieving family blame Tory cutsAlan Forcer was a lance corporal with the Coldstream Guards but suffered years of mental problems after duty in Kosovo. He was found dead in May after walking his dog in woodland near his homeAlan Forcer was  when he joined the Army Image: © Steve BainbridgeByMartyn HalleJohn Siddle:,  Nov An Army veteran died in a ­suspected suicide after the Government slashed funding for a charity that was helping him. Alan Forcer got a letter from Combat Stress saying his PTSD therapy was axed because of a cut to its budget. Alan’s ex-we Claire, , said the loss of his place on an anger ­management course sent him into a tailspin – and he was found dead four months later. Claire, mum to their son Josh, got a text from Alan which read: “DunnoI got the strength to start again.” Alan was a lance corporal with the Coldstream Guards but suffered years of mental problems after horrying duty in Kosovo.  NHS funding for Combat Stress was cut from  onwards.Alan, , got his letter in January  and was found dead in May after walking his dog in woodland near his home in Hartlepool, Co Durham. An inquest will be held next year. The charity’s letter said: “It is with great sadness that we cannot help you at this time. We recommend that you talk to your GP about finding a possible alternative service to help you.”  Claire, from Canewdon, Essex, who remained on good terms with Alan after their split in , said: “I believe Combat Stress losing its money and them having to cancel their therapy work ­contributed to him dying. “He seemed to be turning the corner in  and then their letter arrived. “It gave him a feeling of despair. I think he felt abandoned by people who understood him. “He was now being asked to speak to strangers and start all over again.”  Alan, who joined up aged , saw the bodies of civilians killed in ethnic cleansing horrors in the Balkans. He later suffered complex post-traumatic stress which went undiagnosed for years, said Claire. Through Combat Stress, Alan had been due to go on a six-week therapy course before being referred to the NHS Veterans’ Mental Health Service. Son Josh, , added: “Mum and I thought things were improving until they took the money away for his therapy. You have to be careful how you deal with vulnerable people.” Jeff Harrison, interim CEO at Combat Stress, said: “It was a very dficult decision for us to make as we wanted to be there for every veteran who needed us. “However, the cuts in funding had left us dependent on public donations and unable to provide a critical service to veterans nationwide. “We urge veterans and their families to call our -hour helpline on    or visit combatstress.org.uk.” The Ministry of Defence has ­been contacted for comment. The Samaritans is available  you need to talk. You can contact them for free by calling  , email jo@samaritans.org or head to the website to find your nearest branch. You matter. title: best festive sandwiches tested try
story: Best festive sandwiches tested as we try out Christmas offerings from Waitrose to PretCosta, Starbucks, Waitrose, Tesco, Pret and Greggs are just some of the food outlets we have judged in our mission to find the best festive sandwich on the shelvesReporter Miranda Knox spent an afternoon judging the best Christmas lunches on offer Image: Tim MerryByMiranda Knox:,  Nov | commentsThe countdown to Christmas is on, which can mean only one thing – an abundance of festive sandwiches hitting the shelves. But with so many to choose from, how will you know which one is the best  Here, we test this year’s top meat, veggie and vegan sarnies and rate them out  for both taste and festive factor Waitrose Smoked Salmon, Egg and Truffle, £. With free range egg mayo, Scottish smoked salmon, mushroom and truffle sauce and spinach on rye bread, this sandwich is a fancy twist on festive food. It feels like a nice ‘light’ option, when compared to the others. Taste:  Festive Factor:  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Costa Turkey Feast, £.  This festive sarnie – filled with smoked streaky bacon, pork, sage and onion stuffing and cranberry sauce on malted bread – packs a real punch. It has has just the right amount of sweetness and a good amount of cranberry sauce. However, it is more expensive than its supermarket counterparts. Taste:  Festive Factor:  Tesco Turkey and Trimmings, £.  If ever a sandwich screamed Christmas, this would be it. It comes with sausage, bacon, sage and onion stuffing and cranberry sauce and although the sausage sets it apart from the others, the meat is bland, and it’s a bit dry overall. A great meal deal option, though. Taste:  Festive Factor:  Greggs – Pigs Under Blankets Baguette, from £.  Described as “a tasty baguette with all the trimmings” this sarnie – with sausage, bacon, stuffing and a sweet port and cranberry sauce, is served hot. To be honest, it wasn’t the most appetising to look at and it tasted more like a normal breakfast baguette. Taste:  Festive Factor:  Marks  Spencer Turkey Feast, £.  One of my favourites out of all the homage-to-turkey sandwiches. There’s a big British emphasis on this MS one, which contains British turkey breast with pork, sage and onion stuffing, an onion mayonnaise, cranberry chutney and British bacon. Taste:  Festive Factor:  Morrisons Christmas Lunch, £.  The classic. A turkey sandwich with cranberry chutney, bacon, stuffing and mayo on malted bread. It could have done with a bit more sauce, but there’s a great amount of meat and % from all sales are being donated to Young Lives vs Cancer too. Taste:  Festive Factor:  Subway Tiger Pig, from £.  For a six-inch sub ‘Tis the season for Pigs in Blankets and Subway’s version is a giant pork sausage wrapped in maple-cured bacon, topped with all the trimmings you desire. It’s not overly festive though I ordered a foot-long by mistake, which it was really expensive at £.. Ouch. Taste:  Festive Factor:  Starbucks Blitzen’s Blue Cheese  Chutney Toastie, from £.  This is, in my mind, the ultimate tribute to the Christmas cheeseboard. Deliciously rich, the sarnie is packed with four cheeses such as Stilton, mozzarella, Cheddar and Emmental. Not only is this a fab hot option, but I reckon it would be a great post-Christmas party hangover cure, too. Taste:  Festive Factor:  Waitrose Vegan No Lobster Marie Rose Roll, £  A vegan Brioche-style roll filled with roasted oyster mushrooms in a ‘Marie Rose’ sauce with cucumber and rocket. I had high expectations for this festive sarnie as it sounded exciting but I was left disappointed. It was nothing like a lobster roll, but bonus points for trying something new… Taste:  Festive Factor:  Pret Vegan Christmas Nut Roast, from £.  Whether you’re vegan or not, this one is incredible. It is packed full of butternut squash, rocket and Christmas pesto made from pine nuts and, chestnuts, served with a vegan sage mayo, crispy onions and caramelised pecans. If all vegan food is this good, sign me up. title: boy 16 begs i dont
story: Exclusive: Boy, , begs "I dont want to die" after NHS doctors insist on end-of-le careWilliam Verden, , has a rare kidney disease and needs le saving treatment to keep him alive but medics believe his complex autism means it cannot be carried out properlyAmy believes Williams autism has played a factor in the hospitals decision to stop treatment Image: NB PRESS LTDByAmy SharpeReporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA distraught mum is battling to stop doctors sending her son home for what may be his last Christmas. William Verden, , made a heartbreaking plea: “I don’t want to die. My tubes keep me safe.” Doctors have ruled the teenager, diagnosed with a rare kidney disease two years ago, should no longer have le-saving treatment and receive palliative care instead. Mum Amy, , is aghast at the “death sentence” decision and is prepared to go to the High Court to keep her boy alive. Today, he was well enough to play golf – and can still hit up to  balls on a range. Amy said: “They are sending him home to die. I’ll never let it happen. “If William was in pain or bed-bound then of course I wouldn’t want him to suffer – but he has an incredible quality of le. He plays golf twice a week, I take him shopping, he plays with the local kids. We are in limbo wonderingthis will be William’s last Christmas, or whether he will even make it to thenhe has to go on palliative care.”  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter William, who also has attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and autism, is kept alive through dialysis and without it would have “days or maybe weeks” to live, said Amy. But medics believe his complex autism means it cannot be carried out properly. Doctors treating him at Manchester Children’s Hospital were given a second opinion by an expert from Newcastle who said his kidneys are “devastated” – and a transplant is unlikely to work and carries huge risks. Amy said: “He is probably going to die from this. But he’s not ready to die now. He deserves a chance like everyone.” She fears William’s autism and ADHD have influenced the decision, as many kidney patients receive dialysis for their entire lives. William has interfered with tube lines and entry points, and at times needed restraining during dialysis.  Amy said: “It’s his disability, he’s not interfering with the line on purpose. He hated dialysis at first, then he got used to it – he just needs time. I don’t believe doctors would be advising us in this wayhe wasn’t autistic.”She and William’s dad, Will, , won’t accept Manchester University NHS Foundation Trust’s recommendation.They believe their son should continue to receive therapy and be added to the transplant waiting list. In December , a routine blood test revealed William, then , had focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.  His kidneys were ing at just %. FSGS afflicts around seven in every million people, attacking the kidneys’ filtering units, causing scarring that leads to permanent damage and, sometimes, organ failure. William was initially on steroids but by May , having reached end-stage kidney failure, he was having peritoneal dialysis via his stomach at home. It uses the lining of the abdomen to filter blood inside the body. Amy joined her son at the dialysis machine from pm until am, six days a week. She said: “At first it was horrendous, it took two hours to coax him to get on and he’d have to be occupied the whole time. He would scream and get violent at times.”  Yet William adjusted and led a “normal le”, attending his special needs school until this September, when the tube opening became infected and inflamed with peritonitis. He spent two weeks at MCH, where medics said the treatment was no longer viable. Amy said: “It was the first time they said the words ‘palliative care’.” She begged them to try hemodialysis , where blood is pumped from the body to an articial kidney machine and ed by tubes. She said: “Doctors were not keen because they knew William touched his dressings and picked at his body.” But after a meeting between health trust staff, his social worker and his parents, William had a HD line fitted on September . He began visiting the hospital three times a week for treatment but often screamed, cried and pulled dressings off. Security staff were often needed to restrain him. A consultant’s report said William “tried to disconnect himself repeatedly, putting himself at risk as well as dialysis staff” and sessions often had to be prematurely stopped, resulting in “inadequate dialysis”. William also found the fluid and diet restriction involved in treatment dficult. In the first month, he needed the lines replaced or repositioned three times. On the third occasion, on October , Amy and Will were advised that palliative care would be the best form of action. “I was at a loss for words – then I just said no,” said Amy, who lives in Newton, Lancs. She said: “Yes, there have been dficulties with HD but he’s getting used to it now and just needs more time.” Children with FSGS progressing to kidney failure have a le expectancy of around  years following the start of dialysis but can live an average of  after a transplant. It is unclearthis dfers in those who have ADHD and autism. A letter from the Clinical Ethics Committee at Manchester University Foundation Trust said “every effort” has been put in place to treat William but concludes that continuing would do “more harm [...] than good.” There is an “extremely high” likelihood that FSGS would recur in a transplanted kidney, it found. A consultant from another hospital said he “can only envisage William lurching from one crisis to another on dialysis”. Reinsertion of dialysis lines “will gradually become more dficult” and “may become impossible,” he said, adding: “With these recurrent crises I think it would be highly unlikely he will live long enough to make it to transplant on the waiting list.” Amy, also mum to Levi, , and Ruby, , said: “Since going on HD his bloods are better and so is his quality of le as he’s not tied to the machine for  hours a night. Last week I took him shopping and for lunch – then he went to respite and played pool until pm. “Every Sunday he goes golfing. The other day he walked . miles on the course.” And fun loving William has even dressed up as a chef at his school and as a security guard at hospital. If MFT and William’s parents cannot reach a resolution the courts will have to decide. Amy said: “This whole thing is a nightmare. My daughter is devastated, she cries all the time. I will never live with myselfI don’t fight for him to have this chance.” Liz Davis, of Irwin Mitchell lawyers, which is supporting William’s family, said: “All Amy wants is the best possible le and future for William. We’ll continue to support Amy and the family to ensure their voices are heard.” MFT, which manages the Royal Manchester Children’s Hospital, said: “We recognise that this is a very dficult time for William and his family and we will continue to support them.” Comment MORE ON HospitalsLe expectancySocial workersTeenagersTherapyAutism" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: bubbly mum six who didnt
story: Bubbly mum-of-six who didnt feel bad enough for hospital dies of CovidMandy Morris - who had had both doses of the coronavirus vaccine - became unresponsive at her Liverpool home on Thursday and has sadly passed away, with the family facing a bleak Christmas without herMum-of-six Mandy Morris, from Toxteth, died suddenly this week Image: Liverpool ECHOByCharlotte HadfieldEstel Farell-Roig:,  Nov | commentsA bubbly mum-of-six who didnapost want to go to hospital died of covid after waking up struggling to breathe. Mandy Morris became unresponsive at her home in Liverpoolaposs inner-city area Toxteth on Thursday, November . The -year-old first started experiencing a slight cough and dficulty breathing on Monday and initially put it down to her COPD .But the following day Mandy - who had had both doses of the coronavirus vaccine - decided to take a Covid test which came back positive.A family friend and neighbour said Mandyaposs husband called an ambulance on Wednesday night as he was worried, but that Mandy didnapost feel she was that bad and didnapost want to go to hospital.However, that night she declined rapidly, reports the LiverpoolEcho. Paying tribute, family friend and neighbour Poppy Comer, , described Mandy as a bubbly and funny character, who loved her husband and children dearly. Poppy said: The whole street is absolutely devastated by the shock, it was just so sudden. Sheaposs lived in that street for eight years now and from the day she moved in everyone just loved her. She was such a big character within the street. Everyone who knew Mandy would see how funny and bubbly she was, she was just always making everyone laugh.  When Mandy first started experiencing a slight cough and dficulty breathing on Monday, Poppy said she initially put it down to her COPD. But the following day the -year-old, who had had both doses of the covid jab, decided to take a covid test which came back positive. Poppy said: On Wednesday night her husband was worried about her so he rang an ambulance late in the night but she didnapost feel that she was that bad. She didnapost want to go [to hospital] so they mustnapost have thought she was that bad, so they left and said see how she goes. That night she declined rapidly through the night.  Mandyaposs condition deteriorated further on Thursday morning and, after realising she was struggling to breathe, her husband rang an ambulance. Despite the best efforts of paramedics at the scene, Mandy was pronounced dead in hospital a short time later. She leaves behind her husband Kenny, , and six children - Lesley, , Kyrstine, , Kenneth, , Kristopher, , Kyle, , Krystian,  - who were her whole world. Mandy also leaves behind two granddaughters, Elsie, three, and Ebony, two.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter A Gofundme page has now been set up with the aim of raising money for the funeral and to give her children the Christmas they deserve.Poppy said: Weaposre just trying to give them what we can raise funds for so theyaposre not worrying about struggling for Christmas or struggling for the funeral. In a message on the fundraising page, Poppy said: With Mandy passing away so suddenly and unexpectedly with no time to say goodbyes I thought it would a nice idea to help raise money for her husband and six children. With Christmas around the corner I think it would be amazingwe could all support and give these children the Christmas they deserve. Any donations big or small will help this family as such a sad time. Poppy said the response to the fundraising page so far has been amazing, with people in the L area coming together to donate as well as members of the public who didnapost know Mandy directly. Updated:,  Nov  has warned that the continent is at the epicentre of the pandemic" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _AUSTRIA-HEALTH-VIRUS.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsBooster jabs are the aposbest thing we can doapos to avoid a dficult winter, amid surging Covid rates across Europe, an expert has claimed. Covid cases are rocketing across the continent with rates so concerning a number of nations are re-introducing tougher restrictions despite hopes we had turned the corner on the pandemic. Austria has announced that from Monday it will go back into a full lockdown - the first country in Western Europe to do so and Germany has indicated that it may be forced to follow suit due to soaring infection rates.The World Health Organizationhas warned that the continent is at the epicentre of the pandemic. The UK has the highest number of Covid infections to date in Europe but despite daily infections staying above , for weeks Boris Johnson has no current plans to introduced tougher restrictions.  However he hasnapost ruled out another Christmas lock down yet. UK scientists say the best way to swerve any need to plunge the nation back into a lockdown is to push forward the vaccine programme which includes giving booster shots to double-jabbed Brits. Britain is giving booster doses faster than the rest of Europe and have handed out twice as many doses per head as Austria, France or Germany. A government source praised the % protection rate a third jab can give, telling The Times: Itaposs a much bigger effect than we thought. It absolutely underlines how crucial the booster programme is to get us through the winter. Thereaposs a lot of uncertainty out there but the thing we know with most certainty is that getting boosters rolled out is the best thing we can do. Hereaposs a breakdown of the Covid rates in the  worst-hit countries in Europe and what each Government is doing to tackle the spread of the virus.  UK The UK has the worst number of total Covid infections in Europe with ,, cases of Friday. Its infection rate stands at  cases per , people in the last seven days. The UK has administered at least ,, doses of Covid vaccines so far which is enough to have vaccinated around .% of the country’s population. The nation is still in Plan A of its Covid response with the government refusing to trigger Plan B. Mr Johnson said this week that he saw no need to switch to the new measures which stops short of a lockdown but brings back mask mandates, vaccine passes and work from home orders.  But he has admitted hat he was cautious of rising cases in parts of Europe. He said: We donapost see anything in the data at the moment to suggest that we need to go to Plan B. Weaposre sticking with Plan A. But what we certainly have got to recognise is there is a storm of infection out there in parts of Europe. He also told his Cabinet on Tuesday that while boosters will be the main defence, “we are still not out of the woods and we cannot be complacent”.It has also been reported that children aged five to  are set to be included in the Covid vaccine rollout in the coming months under leaked NHS proposals. Austria The average number of infections in Austria has peaked with , cases per , people in the last seven days.In total, the nation has administered . million vaccines doses which means around two-thirds of Austriaaposs population is fully vaccinated against coronavirus -gtcoronavirus - one of the lowest rates in western Europe.On Monday it will become the first country in western Europe to reintroduce a full lockdown with non-essential shops being closed and Austrians ordered to work from home. The restrictions will be in force until December, but will be reassessed after  days, authorities said. But in addition people will be legally required to be double jabbed by February . Announcing the measures, the Austrian Chancellor said: We have not succeeded in convincing enough people to get vaccinated. It hurts that such measures still have to be taken.  Belgium Belgium has recorded  infections per , people in the last seven days. Belgium has administered at least ,, doses of covid vaccines so far which is enough to have vaccinated around .% of the country’s population. The Belgian Government has toughed up its restrictions this week and has made home-working mandatory four days a week. This is said to have angered some employers and jobs groups. People are required to wear a face mask on public transport and shops, and they must show proof of vaccination or a negative test to enter all hospitality and fitness venues. Children as young as  - it was previously  - now have to wear face coverings too.  Germany Germany has recorded  infections per , people in the last seven days. The nation has a lower vaccination rate than average in Western Europe with nearly % of the population double-jabbed. German health minister Jens Spahn said his country is gripped in a national emergency, with rising cases sparking alarm. He said: We are now in a situation - eventhis produces a news alert - where we canapost rule anything out. We are in a national emergency. Under new rules only people who are double-jabbed or have recovered from the virus will be allowed to access to public spaces like sporting events, cultural shows and restaurants.  The Netherlands has recorded  infections per , people in the last seven days. The nation has administered ,, doses of Covid does so far which means around .% of the country’s population is double-jabbed. The country ed to a partial lockdown last week with the Government ordering restaurants and shops to close early and barred spectators from major sporting events. Supermarkets and non-essential retailers have also been told to close earlier, and social distancing measures will be re-imposed. The government also recommended that no more than four visitors can be at one private home. The stricter rules were sparked angry protests with police force to use water cannons to beat back crowds in Rotterdam on Friday night. Police said seven people, including a number of officers, were injured during the unrest and there were dozens of arrests. The force said the riots had posed a threat to le. Authorities shut down public transportation in the city, closed the main train station and ordered people to go home. FranceFrance has recorded  infections per , people in the last seven days.The nation has administered ,, Covid doses which means around .% of the nation’s population is double-jabbed.Despite the high vaccination rates, France is still seeing a spike in infections. Last week, President Emmanuel Macron said: We have not finished with the pandemic. A Covid pass became a key requirement across France in late July. People need to show proof of vaccination, a negative test or recent recovery from Covid to enter most museums and cinemas and to travel by train and plane. The country has seen a wave of street protests since the measures were introduced.  Spain Spain has recorded  infections per , people in the last seven days.The nation has administered ,, Covid doses which means around .% of the population is double-jabbed.In Spain it is mandatory to wear a face mask in indoor spaces. People are required to always carry a mask in case of finding themselves in a large outdoor crowd whereby .m social distancing cannot be maintained. Masks much be worn in shops, offices, restaurants and on public transport, as well as large outdoor events. However, Carolina Darias, Minister of health announced that the restrictions will be eased little by little.  Italy Cases in Italy are rising and it has recorded  infections per , people in the last seven days.The nation has administered ,, Covid doses which means around .% of the population is double-jabbed.This week the Government brought in a new rule that anyone using public transport must have a aposgreen passapos that shows they have taken a negative PCR test. title: ford fiesta gives new liverpool
story: Exclusive: Liverpool police probe car full of suspicious men seen before hospital bombingCCTV specialists have been at Liverpool Womens Hospital for three days after it emerged that bomber Emad Al Swealmeen could visited the night before the botched attackThe taxi engulfed in fire outside Liverpool Womens HospitalByGeraldine McKelvieInvestigations Editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsCounter terror police are probing a theory that the Liverpool bomber scoped out the maternity hospital where he struck less than a day before the blast. Insiders say CCTV experts are trawling footage from the days before last Sunday’s attack to seeEmad Al Swealmeen was caught on film. Footage is believed to show a blue Ford Fiesta pulling up at Liverpool Women’s Hospital at around .pm on Saturday –  hours before the blast – and staying for around five minutes. The Sunday Mirror understands a member of staff raised the alarm about the car, which is thought to have been carrying five young men. An insider said: “CCTV specialists were at the hospital for three days. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter “They are investigating whether the bomber scoped out the hospital because he has been buying parts since April. They wanted to know whether he had been in the hospital or not. “A blue Fiesta pulled up the night before and it had five men in it. They were acting suspiciously. It stayed for six minutes. They didn’t get out at all. “You can’t make out who the men were from the CCTV. It could have been him and his mates – we just don’t know.” Al Swealmeen, , drew up outside the hospital in a taxi at .am last Sunday. His homemade bomb went off seconds later. Driver David Perry, , miraculou sly escaped before his cab burst into flames. He’s now being cared for at home by we Rachel.  It was originally thought Al Swealmeen planned to detonate his homemade bomb at a nearby Remembrance Day parade. But eyewitnesses insist David, who temporarily lost his hearing, said his passenger had always intended to go to the hospital. One said: “The driver looked in the back just before the bomb went off. He said he saw a red flashing light and the bomber rustling around in his jacket. He heard vibrations and stuff. “As soon as the bomb went off, the back left passenger door blew open and the taxi driver’s door opened.”  A string of hospital staff and passersby helped David and tried to put out the fire before emergency services arrived. A witness said: “The driver wanted to go to the car to get his phone but the car was ablaze. He said, ‘I want my we, I can’t hear.’ His eyes were wide open. “It’s amazing he got out alive. I think the seat took most of the impact. But he didn’t have a Covid screen in place like people have said – which makes it even more incredible he survived.” Security guard Will Cowan,  charged towards the burning car as his horried mum Christine watched but it was too well alight for him to help. Christine had been working in the hospital cafe when the blast happened. Our witness said: “Because Will dealt with it, she was crying her eyes out saying, ‘I thought you were going to die’.” Will’s car was one of two destroyed by the blast. Tonight, he said he didn’t want to speak about the attack. Traumatised staff have been offered counselling. The insider said: “Everyone has been on edge. People have been shaking. The atmosphere is horrible.” And new mums being cared for when the bomb went off have called in to report physical and mental issues. Our source said: “New mums are saying they are having problems.“One said she can’t leave the house, she’s having headaches and can’t hear.Assistant Chief Constable Russ Jackson, Head of Counter Terrorism Police North West, said on Friday his investigation was making “signicant progress” after speaking to Al Swealmeen’s brother. He said: “This has given us an insight into his early years and an understanding of Al Swealmeen’s le and his recent state of mind.” The bomb had ball bearings attached, which would have acted as shrapnel. Mr Jackson added: “Had it detonated in dferent circumstances it would have caused signicant injury or death. “We still do not know why the device exploded when it did, but we are not discounting it being unintentional. “It is a possibility movement of the vehicle or its stopping caused ignition.” Comment MORE ON CCTVHospitalsTerrorismCCTV footageSunday Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: former amazon worker claims employees
story: Former Amazon worker claims employees treated like slaves with no toilet breaksA woman who worked for eight months at an Amazon warehouse in Manchester described the job as exhausting and claimed employees had targets that were not realistic for a humanA former Amazon worker said employees were treated like slavesImage: Getty ImagesByChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov | comments A former Amazon worker has claimed employees at the warehouse where she was based were treated like slaves and could not take breaks to go to the toilet.The woman, who was employed by the online retail giant as an order picker, worked for the company for eight months, earning £. per hour. She was based at a fulfillment centre near Manchester Airport and worked in a ft-long workstation that she described as a cage. The former employee, from Manchester, said she had to find, scan and pack items as quickly as possible - with a target of  items per hour, one every ten seconds. She said she could not take toilet breaks as she feared not being able to reach her target and claimed workers were watched by cameras at all times. The woman, in her s, said she lost weight while working for Amazon and described the job as exhausting. Have you been affected by this story  Email webnews@mirror She told The Sun : They expect you to be like a robot, constantly keeping up your speed without stopping or needing bathroom breaks. Itaposs not realistic for a human.Itaposs really intense because there are cameras everywhere, too, and people constantly walking around monitoring your performance. It was so bad we used to joke with each other, ‘Ready to start your slave labour sht ’ and there was some truth to it. She claimed employees were forced to carry out their duties amid brutal working conditions - and said that after experiencing it first hand, she will never order from the online giant again. The former Amazon worker said she was once told off for ing from her -minute lunch break one minute late and that she received no sympathy when she explained the canteen was  minutes walk from her workstation. She added she avoided going to the toilet when she began working for Amazon because even though managers did not forbid it explicitly, they would tell employees offtheir performance dropped.  The former employee also said that performance indicators, which showed how many items workers managed to pack in a sht, caused anxiety and unneeded stress. She said: In reality, you can’t keep working at the same pace all week because you’re shattered, especially after ­several days of work. She claimed that her knees began to swell after working at the warehouse for two months and her doctors told her she should rest - which she said was impossible at Amazon. In a separate incident, she said her skin became irritated after a product leaked on her arm, but claimed the first-aider did not do anything to help and did not get close to her due to the risk of Covid-. She said that after she went to the toilet to wash her arm, someone went looking for her as she had been missing from her workstation for ten minutes. The woman said other colleagues had similar negative experiences at Amazon and is now urging customers to consider employeesapos alleged poor working conditions when ordering from the retailer. In , former Amazon worker Michael Gabay told The Mirror he completed  days of hell at the biggest UK depot of the worldaposs richest company.He claimed workers walk around like zombies in -hour shts with limited breaks under pressure to work faster, with employees packing , items on the night sht he did at the million sq ft depot in Tilbury, Essex. An Amazon spokesperson told The Mirror the company has a system to recognise workersapos performance, as well as coaching for employees who feel like they need help to reach their goals. The company also added that performance is evaluated over a long period of time and that it is only measured when an employee is at their workstation and logged in to do their job, meaning they can log offthey need to go to the toilet or talk to a manager. The spokesperson added that employees can go to the toilet whenever they need it as toilet breaks are not monitored. They also said that in all the fulfillment centres, employees receive two -minute breaks every day. Amazon said in a statement: Working in a warehouse is not for everyone. But for those who don’t want to sit at a desk all day, it’s a hugely rewarding job. The fact is,you want to work in a warehouse, you’ll want to work at Amazon. In addition to offering excellent pay and benefits we ensure that safety is a priority, that everyone is supported, treated with dignity and respect, gets regular breaks, and works at a comfortable pace. See for yourself by coming on a live [virtual] tour. title: girl 16 can never children
story: Girl, , can never have children after exs dangerous driving ends in disasterThe girl had to give up college and her hopes of becoming a mechanic, as well as being given the earth-shattering news by a doctor that she cannot have children in later leAdam Woodcock outside Warwick Crown Court. Image: Paul Beard   SWNSByPaul SuartGraeme Murray:,  Nov A teenage girl is unable to have children after her ex-boyfriendaposs stunt ended in disaster. Adam Woodcock, , has been jailed for  months after pleading guilty to causing serious injury by dangerous driving that inflicted horric injuries on his girlfriend at the time. She now cannot go out unaccompanied because of a spinal injury she suffered which causes her legs to regularly give way beneath her. The girl also had to give up college and her hopes of becoming a mechanic, a judge at Warwick Crown Court heard.Prosecutor Graeme Simpson said the crash occurred at around pm on the evening of November  last year, CoventryLive reports. “It was dark, and Beausale Lane, a country lane near Warwick, is a twisty, narrow lane. It is well-known as a hazardous road, particularly at night, he said. On that evening Woodcock, of Bishops Tachbrook, near Leamington, was driving his Vauxhall Corsa, to which he had carried out a number of sporty modications. His then -year-old girlfriend was next to him and her two younger brothers in the back. There was loud music playing and as they headed towards Beausale Lane he told them: “I’m going to take you down this really scary road that everyone s**** themselves at.”Woodcock then began racing along Beausale Lane in excess of the speed limit and in damp conditions as one of the boys filmed it on his mobile phone, which was played in court. At one point he lost control of the car and skidded on a bend, but continued to drive in the same way – and the second time he lost control, he hit a tree to the left side of the road.  After the crash, all four of them got out and ran a short distance from the car before the girl, who cannot be named because of her age, found herself unable to stand or even sit because she was in such extreme pain, and she curled up on the ground. Despite her obviously severe injuries, Woodcock, who was extremely concerned about his car, on which he had spent a lot of money on the modications, did not want to call the police – and it was one of her brothers who did so. They were taken to hospital, and although her brothers were discharged the next day, the girl remained in an induced coma for five days.She had a perforated bowel which required surgery and led to her developing sepsis, and a fractured vertebra which left her spine damaged to the extent that she was in a back brace for five months and had to learn to walk again.The impact on the girl, who will require further surgery when she has finished growing, has been utterly devastating. She requires -hour care from her mother, and is not allowed to leave home unattended, on doctor’s orders, because there is dficulty with her brain communicating with her spinal cord, and her legs give way regularly,” explained Mr Simpson. The girl, now , can no longer attend college because of that, with her hope of becoming a mechanic being taken away – and she and her mother were told the sepsis has left her unable to have children. Recorder William Edis QC said: “It is dficult to imagine a more signicant injury to a young woman of her age.” Mr Simpson added: “She and her family have had no expression of remorse at all from the defendant - no apology.”ill require further surgery when she has finished growing, has been utterly devastating. “She requires -hour care from her mother, and is not allowed to leave home unattended, on doctor’s orders, because there is dficulty with her brain communicating with her spinal cord, and her legs give way regularly,” explained Mr Simpson. Queenie Djan, defending, said: “He is a young man of good character. This is his very first interaction with the criminal justice system. “Mr Woodcock has great remorse and great regret for his actions on that night. He is struggling and is broken by the devastation and hurt he has brought on that family as a result of what he’s done. “He knows it will never be enough, but extends his sincerest apologies to the family.” Recorder Edis commented: “I don’t doubt, whether he expressed it to the family or not, that he is remorseful. “He was a typical -year-old with more testosterone than common sense. He was showing off. The only reason he went on that twisty single-track road was to scare his passengers.” And he told Woodcock: “The driving you indulged in was premeditated and deliberate. You deliberately drove down a lane, knowing it would be dangerous, at speeds which were wholly inappropriate resulting in what I consider a predictable outcome. “Some people do like to seek thrills, but where the big dipper is regularly inspected by health and safety, this was a country lane, in the dark, surrounded by solid objects such as trees, and you were going far too fast. “You lost control and your car slammed at some speed into a tree. All of you got out and your initial thought was that none of you had suffered serious injury. “That tragically was not the case, because [the girl] has suffered permanent, le-changing injuries. Her entire le has been altered for the worse. At the age of  she has become as reliant on her family as she ever has been – and that is your fault because you drove catastrophically dangerously. “No sentence other than immediate detention seems to me to be appropriate.” Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Crown courtDangerous driving" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: good pub guide latest lockdown
story: The Good Pub Guide is latest lockdown casualty as edition is shelved for Publishers “very reluctantly” pulled the plug on the  edition after  years as the beer fans most trusted guide, after the lockdown restrictions stopped pub inspectionsToasting the end of an era - at least for now ByJohn Siddle:,  Nov | commentsTime has been called on next year’s Good Pub Guide. It’s the first time in  years the boozers’ bible, which features , meticulously researched British pubs, has had to throw in the bar towel. Marc Hornby, co-owner of the -year-old Virgins and Castle in Kenilworth, Warks, was “over the moon” to make the  guide.He said: “It’s a big shame that there won’t be a  guide. Pubs have gone through a really tough time and the recognition of The Good Pub Guide is an enormous boost.” An Ebury Publishing spokesman said its website will continue to support the industry.  More than , of Britain’s , pubs are said to have been lost to the pandemic.The Good Pub Guide, intended to be a one-off, was started by editor Alisdair Aird using a portable typewriter in his car.Meanwhile, the best city in the UK to go for a pint has been named after research was carried out into the best boozers around the country.Newcastle came out on top, closely followed by Manchester and London.Analysts from business insurance company Bioniclooked at reviews of pubs across the UKto find out which city was the best for craft beer and independent pubs.The company also judged each location based on the number of independent pubs in the area, their average star rating, their unique beers, the number of breweries and their ratings on untapped.  Newcastle was given a metric score of an impressive  out of  based on these six metrics, as Bionic found the city had , pubs in total with  unique beers from its top four breweries on offer.The city on the river Tyne was recently voted the UKaposs favourite place in a poll on our sister site Chill.
