title: help birds animals bed down
story: Help our birds and animals bed down for the winter with Chris Packhams tipsAs the weather gets colder wildle guru Chris Packham shares his tips on how to help furry and feathered friends to stay healthy throughout the winter monthsChris Packham shares his tips Image: BBC Jo CharlesworthByRhian LubinSpecialist JournalistAlex Lloyd:,  Nov | commentsHibernation season is here but while the nation’s wildle beds down for the winter, ­nature lovers should not rest.Conservationist Chris Packham says this cold season is a crucial time of year for Britain’s animals, who need our help to get through it. “There’s never a dead time for ­wildle because wildle always has to be on the go,” the BBC Springwatch presenter says. “Everything is moving through a cycle and in winter there’s an enormous amount of activity.“Some species do all their breeding in winter, like certain moths and fish. Winter is actually a time of richness and le.” Chris, , who first appeared on TV fronting CBBC’s The Really Wild Show  years ago, says it is a misconception that the natural world shuts up shop for winter – and that comes from the prevalence of broadleaf trees. “When we see them looking stark and bare, we think they’re leless, but they are replenishing,” he says.  “If you look at most trees once the leaves come off, they have buds on them for next spring.” Here, Chris reveals how you can help some of the most common hibernating ­animals survive – and thrive – this winter. Get gardening Winter is the perfect time of year to take stock of your garden and prepare for the coming  months. Chris says: “You can see it more clearly as it largely dies back. It’s a time for making decisions, becauseyou wait until spring, it’ll be too late.  “Take a look at your garden in the winter and think, ‘What can I do for it in terms of nature ’ It’s a good time to put a pond in, becauseyou wait until spring it’s too late for the frogs and newts to arrive.” The key to becoming a good gardener is to remain active throughout winter. “It’s the best time to plant trees and shrubs,” Chris says. “If you plant them when they have leaves on and there’s a drought, and you don’t ­water them, they’ll die. “So put them in when there’s no leaves in the winter and they will prosper in spring.” What is hibernation  Hibernation is a state where animals slow down their metabolism to use as little energy as possible over the winter, when food is scarce. Their heart rate drops, as does their breathing, and they survive on fat stores built up over the summer.  It’s called hibernation rather than sleep because the brain cycles the animals go through are dferent. It’s more of an extreme slowing down but only three British mammals truly hibernate – bats, hedgehogs and dormice. Birds have either adapted to the season or ­migrate, while reptiles go into a state called brumation. Box clever for bats Bats are unfairly seen as scary but the world’s only flying mammals make an important contribution to our environment. Chris recommends putting up bat boxes to protect them during the winter months – although they won’t acquire residents until next year.  “Most bat boxes will be occupied in the summer when you’ve either got the males roosting or you’ve got the maternity roost for females,” he says. “In winter, bats want stable temperatures, humidity and air flow, and they can’t get that in a bat box, so they go to hollow trees, caves and concrete buildings. “Butyou put boxes up in spring, it’s too late, because bats go on little foraging flights looking for places when they wake up. “The more you put up, the greater likelihood any one of them being used is. They like to have a network of dferent boxes in the same place.” Feed the birds All garden birds need our help in winter andyou look after them well, you can expect plenty of visitors come the spring. Chris says: “Put up nest boxes. By February, things like blue tits are looking around, thinking, ‘Are there any holes for me to nest in ’ “They don’t lay their eggs until April but by that stage they’ve figured it out. If they haven’t found a nest box in your garden, they will go next door.” Feeders will also help to ensure your resident birds get the nutrients they need – but you have to pay them some attention. “The key thing is to keep them clean,” Chris says. “A number of diseases are sweeping through our finch population. They are generally transmitted by saliva, so it’s the area underneath the feeder you need to keep clean, and the feeder itself. “Putting water out is equally important because birds need to bathe and drink.” Build borders Wooden fences might be easier to erect than hedges but investing in a natural border for your ­garden will pay idends for the ­resident wildle. “Hedges are better than wood – they’re ­going to support more le,” says Chris.  “They take a while to grow and need a lot more maintenance than a fence, so you’ve got to be thinking about whether you are going to be able to make that investment, look after it, trim it and shape it. “Butyou put a fence up instead, it’s a good place to hang bird feeders and bird ­boxes, as long as cats can’t get to them. “Also, make sure you cut a hole in the ­bottom of the fence for hedgehogs to get through – or a bigger hole to help the local foxes and badgers.” Give a hog a home Hedgehogs are one of our most-loved native mammals but, tragically, their numbers have halved since . Their hibernation season is currently under way but Chris says you should not be alarmedyou see one of these spiky little creatures awake.  “It’s not a catastropheyou see a hedgehog in ­winter,” he says. “They don’t go to sleep in October and wake up in March – they will wake up in milder conditions, go out and scramble around to find food. “If they’re tiny, then the likelihood is they might be in trouble and you should think about taking them to a wildle hospital for safety. “Butyou find a bigger animal, the likelihood is that they will move from one hibernation site, come out and have a little forage, then they might go back to it or go to another one.” Hedgehogs need ambulances too Hedgehog rescuer Ellen Cole has nursed  of the animals back to health since finding one on her street five years ago. The animal lover had never seen a real hedgehog until she discovered one covered in burns and unable to see in .  “I wrapped it in a blanket and took it to the vet, who suspected it had been ­accidentally poisoned by de-icer that had fallen in a puddle,” says Ellen, . “Sadly, it had to be put down. But it sparked my interest in how I could help, especially when I found out numbers were declining.” Ellen, from York, now juggles working at her own marketing agency with fostering hedgehogs in need from vets, the RSPCA, Hedgehog Emergency Rescue in Bingley and the Hedgehoggery in Shipley. She also has a network of  volunteers across Yorkshire who act as ambulance drivers for hedgehogs. “People who find one don’t often have the means to get them to an expert so this ensures they can be cared for,” she says. “We’ve transported around , hedgehogs so far.” Next year, Ellen hopes to start a charitable organisation providing hedgehog education to the public. She also recommends creating a “hedgehog highway” in your garden and cleaning out bird feeders once a week. “There are so many hazards for hedgehogs that people are unaware of and would make a big dferencethey made a few changes,” she says.■ Help Ellen by liking the Yorkshire Hedgehog Volunteers page on Facebook. news uk-news i-never-give-up-search-"Katrice Lees father talks about day of her disappearanceByNazrin WilkinsonPhil CardySenior reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov Heartbroken Richard Lee stands at the spot where his daughter vanished on her second birthday  years ago, still clinging to the hope he might one day find her. He is haunted by a mixture of grief and despair – and burning anger at a botched Army investigation into little Katrice’s disappearance from a garrison NAAFI store while shopping with her mum. That fury was only deepened by -year-old Richard’s last meeting with the Royal Military Police who revealed FIFTEEN sex offenders were in the area on the day that shattered his le – before telling him they would only reopen the search for hernew evidence came to light. “To find that out,  years after the event,” he says. “I sat in a room with them and they showed me silhouette pictures of them.  “I know  sex offenders could cover a wide range of offences. But why were we kept in the dark about that  We’ve been let down since day one of the investigation. All I’ve ever wanted is truth and honesty, but I’ve not received that.” His former MP, who was with him at the meeting last December, was also flabbergasted at the RMP’s revelation. Now a retired Sgt Major, Richard, of Hartlepool, has made an emotionalto the village of Schloss Neuhaus, near Paderborn, Germany, to the place where his daughter was last seen – to “stir the embers” and keep the case fresh in people’s memories. It was November , , and Katrice, wearing red wellies and a purple coat, was standing with mum Sharon and aunt Wendy by the checkout at the store – now the site of a conference hall – near her dad’s Army base.  Sharon realised she had forgotten crisps for her birthday party and asked Wendy to watch the tot, but when she ed less than a minute later, Katrice was gone. Wendy told her she had run after her, and she thought they were together. Richard, who had driven them to the store – as big as a medium-sized Tesco – was waiting by his car. Forty years on, he looks around him, recalling the day his le stopped. “When they didn’t come out I went in. Sharon and her sister were in the manager’s office in tears. She told me, ‘Katrice is missing’. I grabbed some of my men and searched the area. “Then the Royal Military Police arrived. Those first few hours were critical – the ‘golden hours’ – but they didn’t even do the simple things like shut the shop and take names and addresses of everyone in there.  “They didn’t interview the women on the tills for six weeks. They questioned me and Sharon in separate rooms. They asked her ‘does Katrice like ducks ’. What two-year-old child doesn’t  In my mind that shows they’d made their mind up without investigating anything properly. “They assumed she’d fallen into the River Alme around  yards away. But it was busy around there. “The college had an open day and the garrison had just ed from a three-week exercise. There were hundreds of people around. Someone would have seen a toddler walking towards the river. Richard, who served in the th th King’s Royal Hussars for  years, firmly believes she was taken. And he has been clinging to hope for four decades.  “I don’t believe she went near the water. I believe she was abducted and is out there somewhere,” he says. “Someone has scooped her up, told her, ‘Let’s look for Mummy and Daddy’ to calm her – and then taken her. “She doesn’t know who she really is – but someone out there does. I will never give up looking for her. No parent would ever give up on their child. Over the years I’ve been to some dark places in my mind. And part of that is coming back here again. “It’s like walking back into any parent’s worst nightmare. I’m living that nightmare. There’s no closure. “I didn’t come here for all the agony and pain this place brings me. I’m here because Katrice is constantly on my mind and in my heart. “I passionately believe Katrice is out there. Hope never dies.”  And neither does Richard’s anger over the RMP investigation which has even astounded his former MP Mike Hill, who was with him at the meeting where the  sex offenders “in the area” at the time were mentioned. He said: “My impression was that it was around the vicinity of the NAAFI. That’s what went into my mind. It beggared belief. There were so many unanswered questions. They didn’t fill in the details. It was quite a deflating meeting for Richard, but I think after all these years he’d anticipated that. What he has been through is just horrendous.” In , a search along the banks of the Alme found bone fragments. Richard said Sharon, now his ex-we, and their older daughter, Natasha, , were “on tenterhooks” waiting for news – only for the RMP to post on social media that they were horse bones. He said: “They did that before informing the family. That shows how we’ve been treated.”  Earlier this month Boris Johnson agreed to meet Richard “father to father” to discuss the case, although a date has yet to be set. Richard said: “I want to speak to him about the treatment of my family.“I’d like to ask why the case has been scaled back  Every missing child needs to be treated equally.” The RMP has previously apologised for failings in its investigation, which included delays in interviewing key witnesses and not releasing a photofit of a suspect for  years. The MOD said: “A review of the investigation in  did not identy any new lines of inquiry. “The Lee family were briefed in person on its outcome and the decision to end active investigations.” Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Ministry of DefenceBritish ArmyMilitary PoliceBoris JohnsonMissing personsSunday Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: inside castle dungeon 12 bedrooms
story: Inside castle with dungeon,  bedrooms and wine cellar - yours for £. millionThe historic property has been altered and extended over the years and comes complete with atmospheric fireplaces, a games room, a wine cellar and an authentic dungeonWoodside Castle, Woodside Estate, South Ayrshire Image: Savills GlasgowByAbi SmillieGraeme Murray:,  Nov | commentsA castle with a dungeon,  bedrooms and wine cellar has gone on sale for more than £. million The expansive pile will be ideal for anyone with deep pockets planning some special yuletide celebrations. Woodside Castle, set in Woodside Estate in South Ayrshire, comes with -bedrooms and six-bathroomsyou are intending having a few guests to stay. It is a A-listed baronial country home, whose tower portion dates back to . But the buyer will need deep pocketsthey want to live in the lap of luxury and wonapost have much change from £.million.The Daily Record reports: The property has been altered and extended over the years and is complete with atmospheric fireplaces, a games room, a wine cellar and an authentic dungeon. Entry to the impressive home is via the grandest of all hallways, complete with a beautully-tiled floor, a roaring fire with log store on either side and a stag head mounted on the wall. Off the hallway on the ground floor is a sitting room, toilet, utility room, dining room, drawing room and kitchen, complete with Tandem French doors which open out into the conservatory. It is being sold by upmarket estate agent Savills which specialises in mansions, country houses and historic properties across the UK  There is ample accommodation upstairs with a choice of bedrooms to choose from. On the first floor are five bedrooms, two bathrooms and a shower room. The master bedroom enjoys a separate dressing room and a spacious en-suite. The second floor provides a further four bedrooms and a shower room, with a spiral staircase leading to the final two bedrooms complete with beautul turret alcoves with windows.  The basement level offers an area for socialising and entertaining as it boasts a games room family room with bar area home office kitchen wine cellar cold store and guest bedroom with en-suite – not to mention the dungeon. Savills says in the castleaposs sales brochure: Downstairs the basement level offers a fantastic area for socialising and entertaining complete with games room, family room with bar area, home office, kitchen, wine cellar, cold store and guest bedroom with en-suite. Not to mention the authentic dungeon.  The grounds of the vast white-fronted pile can be seen from the aerial shots in the literature as can the scale of its extensive grounds. It continues: The gardens and grounds of Woodside Castle comprise some  acres and are enchanting. To the front of the house there are sweeping lawns and a summerhouse with mature trees and herbaceous border  The estate agent goes on to describe the surrounding land. To the north there is extensive woodland with a mix of evergreen and deciduous trees providing year round greenery and texture. To the east of the property is a modern two car garage with potential to be converted or developed. A large well-appointed kitchen is described as superb and offers plenty of space for dining and entertaining.  It offers a range of built in storage options and boasts wooden worktops and integrated kitchen appliances. The estate agent also says features of note include exposed ceiling joists and original stone fireplace. T The property is on sale at offers over £,, from Savills, Glasgow. news uk-news inside-grade-ii-listed-city-"Manchester: Take a tour of The Gardens hotel in city centreByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsThis is the inside of a city centre hotel where rooms start at just £ a night. Guests can stay for a bargain price at The Gardens, located in the heart of Manchesteraposs golden mile. This hotel is easy to miss as its inconspicuous doorway is sandwiched between an hodge-podge of shops on one of Manchester’s busiest pedestrian thoroughfares. The price of rooms starts at £ but that is for the hotelaposs lowest-grade option - the windowless room. Manchester Evening News reporter Diane Bourne spent £. to stay in an executive double room with a window for a night.She says she was pleasantly surprised at how nice her room was.  She wrote: Clearly very recently refurbished, it’s clean, bright and super stylish for a hotel very squarely positioned at the budget end of the market. The bathroom looked like it had only just been fitted, so spotless was every tile and crevice, with a pile of soft fluffy towels at my disposal. She added: And then, lo, inside the sleek black wardrobe was a plastic bag containing that most extra of hotel extras - a super-soft bathrobe and slippers to wear during your stay. My jaw was dropping to the floor at this point - I have to tell you - at the price Iaposd paid for such luxury.  The Gardens hotel is formed inside two merged textile warehouse buildings, the oldest dating back to , and it would later become the offices for the Manchester Corporation Tramways Department. The upper floors of the building were turned into a hotel in the late th century, while the ground level of the building became assorted shops. Old tiling can be seen on a second staircase and an old-fashioned metal lt is still in the older half of the hotel building.  Diane says she could hear the low hum of traffic when she walked into her room and thinks because the building is Grade II-listed that the single-pane windows at the front cannot be changed. She also says there is a Wetherspoons next door. She said she was only able to sleep for half an hour before police sirens woke her up around .pm.  The next morning, she decided to try the breakfast for an additional £.. Diane said: This also turned out to be a right old bargain.The full continental buffet included a little oven with baking pastries and pain au chocolat inside, there was fresh fruit and yoghurts and a coffee machine that spouted out a really delightful cappuccino, while a friendly waiter took my order for a fresh cooked breakfast.The Gardens hotel has a .-star rating out of five on Trip Advisor with many commenting on its great location and prices. title: mum saves hundreds buying second
story: Mum saves hundreds by buying second-hand toys for Christmas - and her kids dont noticeJen Toll, from Oxfordshire, says she saves up to  per cent on most gts by buying them secondhand and can then put more towards experiences for her childrenJen and Ed Toll with their two daughters and dog Image: Jam Press Mark Lord PhotographyByLaura Abernethy, Jam PressEstel Farell-Roig:,  Nov | comments A mum is planning a second-hand Christmas this year - by only shopping at charity shops, eBay and online marketplaces. Jen Toll said she first began her alternative shopping method last year after seeing what her kids were really playing with during lockdown. The -year-old realised that her children didn’t care much about original packaging or the condition of the toys, so she decided to stick with second-hand shopping going forward, particularly as it saves money and is more environmentally -friendly.Jen, from Oxfordshire, said: We had a lot of time at home, of course, to play with toys rather than going out.  “I just felt that, given the state that they were in a lot of the time, they didnapost need to be brand new. “Iaposd always kind of done it but I really embraced it mid-, particularly also for my second daughter who was born in February . “I knew that she was going to have a lot of secondhand stuff anyway from her sister.” For Jen, the most important thing was being more sustainable. Along with her husband Ed Toll, , the pair focused on buying wooden toys, but they knew there would be some things their children wanted that would contain plastic, so they felt buying them second-hand was the best option.The mum said: “I felt that we just donapost need to keep creating more plastic. That was the number one reason.“Very closely tied with that was just how the kids treat the toys. “Iaposm not saying theyaposre constantly breaking them but when they do get played with, stuff does happen to them - theyaposre not always going to be pristine.”  Some of Jen’s best purchases last year were some fancy dress items, particularly as she knew her daughter was growing and they would quickly need to be replaced. She said: “She wanted everything from Star Wars to Elsa but each outfityou get it full price, is really expensive. “My daughter is five and a half but the height of a seven and a half-year-old, and I didn’t want to spend lots on outfits that would only last five minutes. “I focused on getting those second hand. “It was quite funny as getting the right size for her was tricky and we had to pretend Father Christmas had conveniently also got a second one in case the one in her stocking didn’t fit.” This year, the mum has picked up more fancy dress outfits, some talking cuddly toys for her youngest daughter who loves Shrek and even a den building kit for p. She said: “Most of it is in good condition and some of it is brand new as people sell on things that maybe just have never been played with or were bought as duplicate gts. “Some things do come with holes or stains and you just have to be prepared for that. “Last year we got one costume that smells really strongly of fabric conditioner and we never got rid of that smell.” As well as being more environmentally-friendly, Jen says she saves around -% on most gts by buying them secondhand. Know what you want before you start looking and be quite specic with your search terms. You might need to have the conversation around November time because sometimes it takes a little while to find the thing you want. Be patient. Have a look at the recommended retail price so you can know whether you really are saving some money. Look at location -you can get locally, it is going to save postage and of course, a carbon-emitting journey and travel time. The closer you can get it, the better. Askthe seller has got other items. If your child is really into something like they might be selling one thing, buttheir child is a bit older and growing out of something, they might have other things too. You might find something  that your child would particularly like. If you’re not sure of the item’s condition, share with the seller that you’re planning on giving it as a gt and ask them honestlythey think the condition is ok for that purpose. She said: “Sometimes you can get an even bigger bargain. If I take a lot of the outfits I bought last year, typicallytheyaposre new, youaposre looking at £ to £ pounds. I picked most of them up for around about £.” And Jen says her kids haven’t even noticed their toys aren’t brand new.  She added: “My kids are young enough that they have no ideatheyaposre brand new or not. “Within minutes, thereaposs something scratched so it really doesnapost make a dference. They certainly donapost know or indeed care as far as theyaposre concerned. Itaposs coming to them brand new. “When theyaposre a bit older, they might be able to tell and that might bother them but Iaposd like to think that actually, we can talk to them about the reason why buying secondhand is important and that they will embrace that at the time.”Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletterAlthough saving money was never her main aim, Jen says it has helped her put a little more to towards experiences for the girls. She said: “Iaposm a psychologist and know that research does support that having stuff doesnapost make you happy and the boost to well-being when you get gts doesnapost last. “If Iaposm going to spend money, what Iaposd like to spend it on is experiences. “It might sound like Iaposm scrimping and saving but Iaposd much rather get much cheaper toys and bits and pieces and spend money on a ticket to go and see something in theatre, to go out for lunch or to go for a day out. “The studies support that spending money on experiences makes you and that person much happier than on actual stuff.” Comment MORE ON eBayToysChristmas shoppingParenting" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: national embarrassment christmas tree removed
story: National embarrassment Christmas tree removed after locals brand it an insultThe ft cone-shaped articial tree in Grimsby town centre cost North East Lincolnshire Council more than £, but people in the area have been less than impressedA ft articial Christmas tree in Grimsby town centre was removed after locals branded it depressing and underwhelming Image: Grimsby  MEN MediaByPeter CraigMatt JacksonChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA Christmas tree that was branded a national embarrassment has been removed from Grimsby town centre after locals were left disappointed by it. The ft cone-shaped articial tree in the town cost North East Lincolnshire Council more than £,. Locals were baffled when the festive decoration was installed in Riverhead Square on Thursday and several people complained about it, with a resident claiming they had a bigger tree in their house.A person said: That is so embarrassing. Itaposs an insult to Grimsby. Another added: Itaposs a bit of a let down. Could have done better.Following criticism by residents, the Christmas tree was dismantled by contractors shortly before pm yesterday, Grimsby Live reports. Councillor Callum Procter issued a statement to explain why the tree was removed, claiming it was installed too early - and adding that a bigger one will be installed in the town next week. He said: There are great plans for celebrating the start of the Christmas period next week. Unfortunately, the Christmas Market tree was installed too early, and we understand that people were confused and thought this was our civic tree. The tree has been removed temporarily today and our contractors are reinstalling again, for free, ahead of the market next week. I’m looking forward to seeing people enjoying the illuminations, the market, and the revamped St Jamesapos Square with the civic tree and the special lighting on the Minster as part of the Christmas experience. The main Christmas tree will be situated in St Jamesapos Square from Monday, with the tree lights being switched on from pm on Thursday. A council spokeswoman said: There is no larger light up event this year as a Covid precaution.Earlier this month, people in a Merseyside village criticised their areaaposs festive display after their Christmas tree was replaced by one they say looks even worse.Blake Maynard, who lives in Birkdale village, Southport, in the borough of Sefton, took to a local Facebook group to rant about the tree earlier this month.After he compared the excuse of a Christmas tree to a beanstalk and another person askedit had been dragged out of the canal, Sefton Council agreed to replace it. However, it looked like the issue was not resolved as locals were still unhappy with the new display. title: night time toilet habit could
story: Night time toilet habit could be sign of aggressive cancer, warn medicsNocturia is a condition that causes you to wake up during the night to urinate, according to the Cleveland Clinic - and could be a sign of prostate cancerProstate cancer is the second-most common form of disease among men after skin cancer Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA toilet break at night could be a sign of an aggressive cancer, medical experts have warned. If you have a sudden or increased need to urinate throughout the night it could be a sign of prostate cancer. Nocturia is a condition that causes you to wake up during the night to urinate, according to the Cleveland Clinic. Severe nocturia has been found in  per cent of prostate cancer cases as a side effect of radiation treatment, studies have shown.The condition can also result from a tumour that is growing in size and pushing against the urethra, Thereports.  The Cleveland Clinic says: This can be thought of as nocturnal urinary frequency - having to urinate more often at night. Nocturnia typically occurs in the later stages of the disease, meaning treatments must start right away.The NHS notes that: “Prostate cancer does not usually cause any symptoms until the cancer has grown large enough to put pressure on the tube that carries urine from the bladder out of the penis. Symptoms of prostate cancer can include needing to pee more frequently, often during the night. Early prostate cancer can be dficult to detect due to the lack of obvious symptoms. According to Prostate Cancer UK,you are aged  or over, your father or brother has had the disease, or you are black, you should speak to your GP. The drop in cancer screening rates during the Covid- could have repercussions for cancer survival in the coming years.There is overwhelming evidence that diet is a strong determinant of cancer.There is growing evidence that a plant-based diet may lower the risk of disease and slow its spread.Those who eat more fruits, vegetables, legumes and fish are less likely to see their cancer grow to the point of needing treatment, researchers have determined.These foods contain naturally occurring plant compounds, known as carotenoids, which could protect the body against DNA damage.Red-coloured fruits are particularly apt at protecting the body against cancer, due to their lycopene content, studies have found.Eating canned tomatoes slashed the risk of prostate cancer by  per cent in a  study published in Cancer Causes and Control. Prostate cancer is the second-most common form of disease among men after skin cancer. The disease is often labelled aggressive for its ability to spread quickly to neighbouring lymph nodes and organsleft untreated. Doctor Bradley McGregor, an oncologist with the Hard-affiliated Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, said: The same dietary habits that can lower your risk of prostate cancer can have a similar effect to perhaps slowing its spread. So, no matter where you are in terms of prostate cancer - from monitoring PSA levels to treating a diagnosis - take the opportunity now to get serious about your diet. news uk-news pensioner--overjoyed-egyptian-toyboy-"This Morning: Iris Jones reveals what she did on her wedding dayByPatrick Hill:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe pensioner who shocked Britain by marrying an Egyptian toyboy  years her junior has been reunited with him after a year-long wait for him to get his visa. But despite her previous frank revelations about their sex le Iris Mohamady, previously Jones, , said she and Mohamed, , simply toasted his arrival in the UK on Friday with “a cup of tea”. The retired care worker told the Sunday Mirror: “We didn’t celebrate – we are just together and that’s celebration enough. “We just had a cup of tea together. Mohamed is happy but he can’t say much at the moment. He’s one of those reserved Egyptians.”  Mohamed was granted a three-year visa on November  after he passed the required English language test and showed proof he was able to move in with Iris. She was shopping when he rang to tell her the good news. As Mohamed put his arm around her and kissed her on the head, she recalled: “There was a lot of happy shouting and screaming. I cried in Tesco while sorting out my fruit and vegetables. “My tears were dripping on the apples. It was amazing.”  She travelled by coach from her home in Weston-super-Mare, Somerset, to collect him from Heathrow. Speaking from her £, semi-detached bungalow, Iris said: “Three buses there and three back. We were worn out.”The couple first started chatting on a Facebook group for atheists in the summer of .They met in person the following November and wed in Cairo a year later.  But since December, their only contact has been phone or Facebook chats. Iris described their year apart as “awful”. She shot to fame last year when she told the Sunday Mirror about their sex le. Iris revealed they became romantic hours after meeting and said: “It was incredible. I felt like a virgin again. It wasn’t easy but it was very loving and romantic. “My ex-husband said I was frigid when we orced  years ago but I now know I’m certainly not.” Engineer Mohamed plans to find work in the UK. Iris said: “As for the future, who knows. It depends on how long I last.” The mum of two sons, Stephen, , and Darren, , said some relatives gave her the “silent treatment” after she married Mohamed. But she said: “We love each other. That’s all that matters.” Comment MORE ON LoveSunday Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: playstation 5s selling 1000 online
story: Exclusive: PlayStation  selling for £, as online vultures prey on Christmas buying panicFamilies are urged to not to panic-buy to deliver the much sought after PS consoles this Christmas despite scalpers buying up stocks so they can charge inflated pricesThe PS could be like gold-dust this year - again Image: Bloomberg via Getty ImagesByStephen Hayward:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsFamilies face spending up to £, for a PlayStation  this Christmas as online vultures continue to cash in. A shortage of new consoles means many will have to use re-sale sites to get one. With  days to Christmas they are going for % more than the £ RRP – and that is set to soar as the big day looms.A global lack of microchips has left Brits scrambling to find stocks of Sony’s console and its Microsoft rival, the Xbox Series X.To make things worse, dealers – known as scalpers – wipe out online stocks before ordinary shoppers get a chance, then sell them at a huge profit. Some retailers limit orders to one console per user and run payment checks to prevent multiple buys.More than a million PSs have been sold in the UK since last November. While they were back in stock last week at Argos, Curry’s and Smyths Toys, other retailers such as Amazon and Tesco had sold out.Andy Robertson, editor of the askaboutgames website, urged PS fans not to panic-buy.He said: “I appreciate it’s the ‘must have’ gt. But you take a risk when you buy on an auction site because it’s not an official retailer. “I suggest parents either go for the cheaper PS option or just bide your time.”Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TescoArgosAmazonMicrosoftChristmas shoppingPanic-buyingPlayStation Sunday Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news queen-expected-attend-double-royal-"Queen greets General Sir Nick Carter at Windsor CastleByTom Ambrose:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments The Queen is expected to attend a joint-christening ceremony on Saturday and Princess Eugenie and Zara Tindall christen their babies. The monarch has had to pull out of a string of public events in recent weeks, including a scheduled appearance at the Cop climate summit in Glasgow and the Remembrance Sunday ceremony, due to a back sprain. But The Sun newspaper has reported that she is planning to attend as the second cousins are baptised on Saturday at All Saints Chapel in Great Windsor Park, Berkshire.It is understood she will take a decision on the day and consult with her personal doctor in advance. Others in attendance will likely include Prince William and Kate Middleton. Get our daily newsletter for the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up A royal source said: “Her Majesty is very keen to be there as she knows how important this is for her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. It’s set to be a heartwarming family occasion and a time of real celebration after what has been some challenging times for certain royals of late, including the Queen herself. “She is keen to attend such a wonderful event after the great personal disappointment of missing last Sunday’s Remembrance events.” It is thought tomorrow is the first time members of the Royal Family will have been baptised together.  Princess Eugenie and husband Jack Brooksbank’s son August was meant to be christened in July before the event was cancelled due to Covid. He will be baptised alongside Lucas Philip, the son of Mike and Zara Tindall, born in March. The ceremony will be led by Canon Martin Poll, who is chaplain to Great Windsor Park and will take place at the private Grade-II listed church which forms part of the Royal Lodge house. news uk-news range-shoppers-who-queued-through-"The Range give tour of their new store in BuryByThomas MolloySeamus McDonnellTim Hanlon:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsShoppers who queued through the night expecting £, prizes at a new The Range store were left furious at what they were given when the doors opened. Avid bargain-hunters were seen queuing up with camping chairs and blankets from pm ahead of the Bury shop opening its doors at am on Friday.Advertising from The Range promised the first  customers through the door would receive a gt bag with prizes worth over £, to celebrate the th store, reported the Manchester Evening News.But shoppers were left disappointed with some only receiving gts that they valued at just £ or £.  The Range has since explained that the total value of prizes and gt cards given away to the first  customers was £,. A spokesperson for the store claimed there were still a lot of satisfied customers and that the first three people in line won big prizes including £ vouchers, a hot tub, a kayak and a paddle board. But, others who had waited through the night for the doors to open were less pleased. Emma Louise said: We were promised a £, grand prize I got there at am with good faith that I was going to win. Waited four hours, spent so much money on hot drinks to stay warm.  Finally, I received my bag, it had a pack of pencils inside, a bath bubble, a moisturiser, a bag of chocolates and gt card. When I spoke to the woman I asked her how much was on it and got told it would be between £ and £. Went to the till and the women said I had won ‘’ I said aposwhat £apos she goes no apos£apos! I was so upset not only did I waste my time, I wasted my money on £ taxi to get down and £ on hot drinks to stay warm. Feel very let down. Another shopper said: In the bag there was a bottle of bubble bath, body lotion, a trolley coin, bag of chocolate, out of date edible cake decorations, packet of pencils, cup cake cases, Minky cleaning pad, and a gt card which we had to take to a till to find out the value, we and everybody around us had a fiver in it. It was obvious they had worded the press release in a way to make it look like it was worth queuing for so they had nice pictures. I was there for am but there were one or two people who had been out all night. I just hope they got one of the decent prizes promised! The Range said over  shoppers queued for the new store - the th Range branch in the UK. A statement from The Range read: Three excited shoppers who had stayed outside of the store overnight bagged themselves a goody bag with a £ gt card to spend in store and amazing spot prizes. First through the doors was -year-old Claire Chapman who received a Lay-Z Spa hot tub. Ryan Wright, , who was second in the queue, received Kayak and sail, while the third person in the queue, -year-old Tracey Kerr, received a stand-up paddle board. All of the first  shoppers through the doors received a goody bag which contained gt cards ranging from £-£ and spot prizes which included love to shop vouchers, drill sets, door mats, art deco bin, electric heater and lots more household goodies. The total value of prizes and gt cards given away to the first  customers was £,. title: some brits dont leave home
story: Some Brits dont leave home due to bladder issues and the nationwide shortage of loosIn the past six years numbers have fallen by  per cent, and now a survey has revealed that one in five Brits fear leaving home because of their bladder issues.Many councils have closed public toilets to save cash Image: Getty ImagesopinionByRachael Bletchly:,  Nov | commentsWhen I was a child, shopping trips into town with my mum always involved several wee stops. Every time we passed a public convenience she had to pop in and spend a penny. Because, mum said, she didn’t want to get caught short in Mac Fisheries or be bursting for a wazz in Woolworths. So, of course, I am now a preemptive piddler too. AndI pass a public lav when I’m out I’ll pay a visit “just in case”. But it irritates friends who know that I can easily hold on until we reach the cafe or pub and use the Ladies there. Because I am not constrained by the dreaded “urinary leash” that causes misery for millions of elderly, disabled and vulnerable people. The people tied to their own homes by a fear of being caught short and the nationwide shortage of loos. Councils are not legally obliged to provide public toilets, so many have now closed theirs to save cash. In the past six years numbers have fallen by  per cent, and now a survey has revealed that one in five Brits fear leaving home because of their bladder issues. Some people who could wait don’t bother trying though – they just relieve themselves in the streets and people’s gardens. Then there’s “flypeeing” where people widdle in bottles or coffee cups and lob them out of car windows. The Royal Society for Public Health calls the dwindling number of public loos “a health and mobility inequality we cannot afford to ignore”. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter And the British Toilet Association is campaigning for them to be kept open as part of the drive to reinvigorate our high streets and support local shops and traders. Because how can you expect people to splash the cash when there’s nowhere in town to spend a penny  We Brits are famous for our lavatorial humour. But the shortage of public conveniences now facing this country is no laughing matter. And we have to protect our right to carry on at our convenience. The BTA’s “Use Our Loos” campaign is urging businesses to make their toilets accessible to the local community and for shops, cafes and bars to let people use theirs for free. They are also supporting the Great British Toilet Map, a database to help you find the nearest ones, and to link existing community toilet schemes across the country. One of those is an “Age Friendly” project, where shops display logos offering older people wee stops. It’s in Banbury, Oxfordshire, where I grew up. And my mum would be simply delighted. title: terrified mum clung baby violent
story: Terried mum clung to baby as violent ex told her  you scream, Ill finish the jobEllie Fairhurst from Kinmel Bay in North Wales has relived her "le of hell" after her ex-partner narrowly avoided being sent to jail this weekEllie Fairhurst has said she feared for her le when her violent ex-boyfriend attacked her in a jealous rage Image: Ellie Fairhurst WALES NEWS SERVICEByAaran LennoxEstel Farell-Roig:,  Nov | commentsA mum has been left with permanent injuries after a violent ex-boyfriend lashed out at her in a jealous rage.Ellie Fairhurst has revealed her le of hell and described desperately holding on to her crying baby following an unprovoked assault by Anthony Martin.While she cowered in terror, the ex-boyfriend told her thatyou scream, I will finish the job and also threatened to throw acid in her faceshe told anyone. Earlier this week, Martin narrowly avoided being sent to jail for punching her to the floor during an argument last year.The -year-old woman described the dad-of-seven as a real danger to women in her victim impact statement, reports the DailyPost. Ellie shared pictures of the injuries Martin inflicted on her which were shown in court this week and told how Martinaposs abuse left her a shadow of the person she once was.She said: I was made to fear for my le the night I was attacked. Anthony kept shouting things at me, the one that sticks in my mind is: ‘If you scream, Iaposll finish the job,’ whilst standing over me holding my crying baby, who had woke from the noise.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter I couldn’t call for help because I didn’t know what would have happened next. I don’t know what would have happened to my baby, and the thought of him growing up without a mummy hurts alone. The unprovoked attack still haunts me to this day and something which I think will haunt me forever. Being forced to stay quiet in my own home, whilst in so much pain.Earlier this week, Martin - of Llugwy Road in Kinmel Bay, north-east Wales - admitted two counts of common assault, along with cultivating cannabis plants and siphoning electricity. He was handed a -month suspended sentence, ordered to carry out  hours unpaid work and to complete an anger management course. A letime restraining order was imposed to protect Ellie, who is also from Kinmel Bay. But choking back tears, she questioned how he could have got off so lightly and admitted sheaposd lost faith in the justice system.  I feel totally let down...and I will not continue to be silent like I have been made to be for the past  months, she said. Ellie explained how she saw outbursts of anger and abusive behaviour within months of their relationship. She said: The attack wasn’t the first, I cannot forgive myself for not screaming for help that night or months before then when I noticed Anthony’s controlling nasty behaviour. Truth be told, I honestly believed this man was capable of killing me as he threatened to do so countless times over the months of knowing him. Therefore I was far too scared of him to do anything about it. He had no care about anyone other than himself.  Do you have a story  Email webnews@mirror. After she was punched by Martin, Ellie went to Glan Clwyd hospital to have her right eye examined. Doctors confirmed she had suffered a cracked nasal wall which had left her with an eye haemorrhage. As a result, she needed specialist treatment at Abergele Eye Hospital. I was struggling mentally at the time in facing up to what had happened, I hated what I had become - a victim and absolute shadow of the person I was before, she admitted. After several appointments, Ellie was referred to her doctor after persistent numbness in her right cheek and stinging sensations in her eye. She was told that it was very unlikely that she would ever fully regain the feeling back in her face and that over time it may only get worse. She added: I will continue to fight to get better for the sake of my son because he deserves the best mum I can be. Never will I forget this bad memory, I think it’s going to have an effect on me forever, it changed me from the person I once was. The physical reminder I have will forever be there due to his actions, which is something I find really dficult to live with. news uk-news thousands-evacuated-lakeside-shopping-centre-"Essex: Lakeside shopping centre evacuated after power cutByMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThousands of shoppers have been evacuated out of Lakeside shopping centre following a major power cut. Shoppers were plunged into darkness this afternoon at the mall in West Thurrock, Essex. In videos, shared on social media, huge crowds of people could be seen exiting the area - with even Santa spotted walking with his elves.One person on Twitter urged people to avoid the shopping centre.Tristan Jabez tweeted: Avoid Essex #Lakeside widespread power cut. Long queues for exit and police presence. One unhappy shopper said the lights had switched off just after theyaposd ordered a chicken dinner. Have you been caught up in the power cut  Email webnews@mirror  They were left unsure how to get the food or a refund. Iaposve placed an order in Lakeside Shopping center branch, they tweeted at KFC. Fire has been reported meanwhile and we are all evacuated and looks like we are not getting back inside anytime soon. How do I get the refund  UK Power Networkaposs website shows there have been two separate power incidents in and around the West Thurrock area, with more than  affected postcodes and  calls received. Another person posted a video on Twitter showing staff escorting people out of the shopping centre with torches. They wrote: All power off at Lakeside Essex. We all had to evacuate. Hopefully just a power failure and nothing more serious. Essex Travel News also tweeted there are major delays on the M following the blackout and swell of traffic onto the motorway. They wrote: M Clockwise: Slow moving traffic between Jand J . Many people were stuck in the car park for more than an hour due to the rush to leave the site. Lakeside has been contacted for comment. title: trophy hunters face seven years
story: Trophy hunters face seven years jail as stars urge support for new lawLabour MP John Spellar’s plan is supported by celebrities and across the political ide, including by Tory MPs. It would make importing threatened or vulnerable species an offenceThe new bill would make importing threatened or vulnerable species an offence Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByChris McLaughlinPolitical reporter:,  Nov | commentsHunters smuggling in big game trophies face seven years’ jail under a planned new law. And all owners of hunting trophies – such as lion skins, tusks, antlers, heads and other macabre souvenirs – would have to register or face jail.The changes, proposed in a Bill, come after legislation promised by PM Boris Johnson two years ago has failed to appear.Labour MP John Spellar’s plan is supported by celebrities and across the political ide, including by Tory MPs.Hunters can import trophies of animals, including polar bears and reindeer, ­under a limited number of Government licences.The Hunting TrophyBill would make importing threatened or vulnerable species an offence, with culprits facing up to seven years in jail.  It would bring trophy smuggling into line with laws covering the import of ivory from elephants and rhino. Mr Spellar said: “It’s time for action, not words. We need to make sure that these sick imports are stopped and the only way to do that is to make it a crime.” Actress Dame Judi Dench said the Government should back the Bill to show its “determination to ban animals being senselessly slaughtered for souvenirs.”  Downton Abbey star Peter Egan said: “Wildle can’t wait any more. “Every year that goes by without this ban in place means ­hundreds more animals are killed just for kicks.” The private members’ bill is likely to need Government support to become law. Spoof of evil offer Campaigners have produced spoof ads to shame hunters and their “sport” of shooting animals for fun. The ads for “Trophy Hunting Holidays” mock real offers marketed by the trophy hunting industry. Huge posters from the -second social media parody launched today will be circling Parliament from tomorrow. Voiced by Peter Egan and Vikings actor Richard Ashton, it offers “hot new deals” such as two-for-one lion kills, cheetah hunts for £,, giraffes for £, and elephants for £,. Campaign Against Trophy Hunting’s Eduardo Goncalves said: “It’s funny in a dark way but the idea is to show just how grotesque and twisted the industry is.” Comment MORE ON Peter EganJohn SpellarBoris JohnsonJudi DenchDownton AbbeyPolar bearsPoliticsAnimalsChristmas partySunday People" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news uk-weather-freezing-icelandic-air-"UK Weather: Temperatures forecast to plunge across the UKByChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA surge of Icelandic air is set to hit the UK in the final  days of November and the beginning of December, with snow arriving and temperatures plunging to as low as -C.Forecasters said high pressure from the Atlantic and a trough over the North Sea and Continental Europe will be the main weather patterns during this period.Northerly winds are expected around the country, with outbreaks of rain and snowfalls likely in Scotland. BBC Weather forecaster Sarah Keith-Lucas said that after a mild start to this weekend, weather conditions will change over the next  hours.She said: Itaposs turning much colder through the course of the weekend, November has been a mild month so far but things are about to change now.  This afternoon, northern areas will turn quite cool and blustery with a mix of sunshine and heavy showers, Ms Sarah Keith-Lucas said. Southern areas will remain mostly cloudy and mild with some patchy rain in places, with temperatures remaining between C and C. Tonight, most of the country will see clear skies but showers will continue moving in from the north. Ms Sarah Keith-Lucas said: Temperatures in most of our towns and cities will remain a few degrees above freezing, but expect a frost certainly in the most rural spots first thing tomorrow morning.  Tomorrow will be a sunny and dry day for most of the country, but it will feel rather breezy, forecasters said. Next week will start on a dry note but on Wednesday, showers are likely to hit the South East. Ms Sarah Keith-Lucas said it is now time to dig out winter coats as temperatures keep getting colder.The Met Office warned of heavy snowfall in the north of the UK on Monday, with the cold blast predicted to reach the south by Wednesday night. Most of the UK will see sub-zero temperatures with C expected in many areas, as well as lows of -C. Initially, southern England will not be as cold, but forecasters said by November  it is set to be freezing in London, drop to around -C in Newcastle and in the Scottish Highlands it could get to -C. Met Office forecaster Marco Petagna said: I couldnapost imagine a better weather pattern for cold weather fans, with forecast models showing a northerly straight from the Arctic next week. UK  day weather forecast Today: Dry and fairly cloudy across southern areas. Further north a band of mostly light rain moves southwards and reaches central areas by the end of the day. Showers follow the rain across north and northwest, falling as snow over hills. Tonight: Light patchy rain clears from southern areas. A rather cold northerly wind follows across all parts, mostly dry inland, but showers moving inland from north-facing coastlines. Sunday: Rather cold but dry and bright for most locations, however, showers will feed inland from the North Sea coastlines. Outlook for Monday to Wednesday: Initially settled and mostly dry with iable cloud cover. During Wednesday a band of rain moves southeastwards across northern areas, colder conditions and showers follow, showers wintry over hills.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON SnowWeatherMet Office" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman abandoned baby reunites mum
story: Woman abandoned as baby reunites with mum  years later but only as friendsAnne Harrison, , was left at St Cross Hospital in Rugby in Warcs. after her mum, who came from Barbados, fell pregnant and was unable to look after her - after years of searching she was finally able to find herAnne Harrison finally met up with her mother but says she still wont acknowledge her as her daughter Image: CoventryLive  WSByLata YedroudjAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA woman who was abandoned at a hospital as a baby reunited with her mum  years later. Anne Harrison, , was left at St Cross Hospital in Rugby in Warcs. after her mum, who came from Barbados, fell pregnant and was unable to look after her.The baby was placed in an orphanage and later a white couple offered to foster her, CoventryLive reports.Anne soon realised she was dferent in school because of her skin colour and was taunted and bullied by her peers. She said: It wasnapost until I started going to school that I realised I was dferent.  I had dferent skin and I was taunted and teased and children called me bad names. My white foster carers didnapost treat me dferently to any member of the family. They used to tell me to ignore the kids at school, but within the family, I was treated as one of them. Anneaposs foster parents emigrated to Australia when she was nine and she was moved to a childrenaposs home. At , Anne received the shocking news that she had a younger brother living in a separate childrenaposs home.  She said: When I was about  or , the authorities were informed by the police that my mum likely had a breakdown and was at the hospital. She told the police officers that she had a son who lived in Berkshire at the time, and she had a daughter as well, which was me. We were both in dferent childrenaposs homes. Fortunately, weaposre both very close and we see each other on a regular basis. Anne started to look for her mum when she was . Anneaposs mother would write letters to her but refused to meet her children in person. One day, Anne made a trip to London to seeher mother was at one of the old addresses she was writing from - but she wasnapost there. Anne decided to focus on her career but still kept searching for her mother. That same year, when Anne was  she began working as a police cadet for Warwickshire Police and left the childrenaposs home to live in provided accommodation by the police force.  At , Anne was a working police officer and after three years in the force, she decided to leave to become a social worker starting in Stratford, East London and then moved to Coventry. She said: When I first came to Coventry I would very rarely see another black person. I was so confused about how to look after my hair, how to deal with my skin, were there any other people who looked like me. I was brought up in a white household, my foster parents were white.  The childrenaposs home was predominantly white, being in the police force was predominantly white. I was one of the first black police cadets in Warwickshire. In her late s, Anne was able to locate her mum. She agreed to meet Anne and they set up a date to see each other for the first time. Anne says she was overwhelmed when she met her mother for the first time. Anne said: I was a little overwhelmed. It was like looking at a mirror of myself, but it was emotional.  I knew that she had been crying before we met. She still would not acknowledge me as her daughter, she kept saying we were meeting as friends. There was still that barrier and it still exists today. Anne has met her mother at least eight times over the years - but it was always at a distance. She added I know very little about her or what she chooses to tell me. A little bit comes out each time we meet. Itaposs little steps, but itaposs very much a distant relationship and I had to accept that this is as far as it goes. Anne and her brother now live in dferent cities but are very close and see each other regularly.Anne has released her biography, aposCall Me Auntieapos, about her le in care and the search for her mother available to purchase here. title: woman says hermes ruined christmas
story: Woman says Hermes has ruined her Christmas after disgusting delivery of gtNicola Rooney, , claims Hermes left her husbands surprise present on their doorstep in Birkenhead, Merseyside - a site which countless people walk past each dayNicola Rooney, , has slammed Hermes after a delivery of a gt on her doorstep in Birkenhead, Merseyside went missingByRebecca KoncienzcyRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov  A woman says Hermes has ruined Christmas for her husband after a disgusting delivery. Nicola Rooney, , from Birkenhead, Merseyside, had been waiting  days for a Remington shaver to arrive - a surprise gt for her partner Tank, .As the days went on and the parcel didnapost appear, she contacted the online retailer, Studio, to ask about the hold up.She told the Liverpool Echo : I ordered a £ Remington shaver for my husband and was wondering where it was, because it doesnapost take  days to get here.When I contacted Studio they said it had been delivered. I checked with Hermes and they had a picture of it just on the doorstep. I never received this, it was clear from the picture I didnapost receive it. Nicolaapos says she was disgusted because it was obvious that they left it while knowing no one was there to sign for it. She said: It is disgusting. You can clearly see in the picture no one was there to take the parcel, they usually have photos of a delivery showing the door open, but this is obviously closed. It is really frustrating because we live on the corner and everyone can just see it. It has completely ruined Christmas for him [Tank] because there is no surprise. Nicola says Studio agreed to refund the money and send a new shaver. She added: It is the principle of the matter. I have seen similar things like this happen to others. Something needs to be done, Hermes has a duty of care, they should be named and shamed. I am lucky, it wasnapost massively valuable and I have had a refund. But it could have been something very expensive so to just dump it is unacceptable, they are not taking any pride in this. A spokesperson for Hermes said: We have been in contact with Ms Rooney to apologise for any inconvenience and provide her with a full refund so that she can order another shaver in time for Christmas. This is a very busy time of year and our local couriers are working hard to deliver, so we would ask that people try to be at home when expecting a delivery or choose an alternative service such as deliver to a neighbour or ParcelShop where available. Anyone experiencing delivery issues should contact their retailer or seller in the first instance, who will in turn contact Hermesrequired. news uk-news womans-incredible-house-makeover-thrty-"Woman gives outdated house incredible makeover with hacksByRia Newman, Jam PressEstel Farell-Roig:,  Nov | commentsA woman has given her outdated home an incredible makeover using thrty DIY hacks - and says she has added £k to the propertyaposs value in the process.Rima Aktar bought her three-bedroom home for £, in May last year alongside her husband.The -year-old said the home was very outdated with blue walls and damp carpets throughout – but the Liverpool couple knew with a bit of TLC it could be the perfect base. Equality and ersity lead Rima said: “My main goal was to add storage as my home didn’t have a lot of it. “We made a DIY pantry area in the kitchen and added fitted wardrobes in our bedroom which perfectly fit into the alcoves.  “I also wanted to add ling in almost every room, however we wanted to do this ourselves to save cost and be under budget.“We learnt how to do it from Instagram tutorials and it’s honestly one of the most proudest achievements we have done with the house.”The couple said that, while they didn’t want to do a major renovation or throw too much money at the property as they don’t consider it their “forever home”, they were determined to give it a fresh makeover that better suited their tastes.  They set about decorating in November , painting the walls in neutral tones, ripping up the carpet to let the wooden floor breath, and adding ling to the walls for a touch of glamour. The couple also experimented with other DIY tasks including creating a makesht pantry in a small corner of their kitchen, which they led, painted white and then screwed on some rustic-style shelves purchased from eBay. Also in the kitchen, they made DIY shaker-style cabinets. They purchased MDF wood cut to their specications that cost £, and then fitted them.They also created a DIY Crittall-style shower screen for £ by painting the frame black using a £ tester pot, then using a mm vinyl tape she bought from eBay for £ and cut to , sticking it on the glass. For extra precision, she used a spirit level. To furnish the home, they scoured Facebook Marketplace for second-hand furniture.Rima estimates each room in the house took between - weeks to complete – with the couple usually working on them during the weekends. They did all of the work themselves, aside from fitting their wardrobes, which they hired professionals to do.  Rima said: “The most dficult part was the painting – we have high ceilings and we found it to be draining at times, but it was worth it. “We live in a fairly old house so wall cracks appeared which were dficult, but we have accepted that some of it adds to the character.” In total, the couple have spent £, on the renovations – including the cost of the fitted wardrobes. Now, the couple are focusing on transforming the two spare bedrooms and giving the hallway a mini makeover. Rima added: “I have come to the conclusion that I will always have some decorating to do. “But my husband has been my partner in DIY and I wouldn’t have been able to execute half of the ideas or plans without him – he truly is a gem.” Rima claimed the house value has increased by £, already and that she anticipates it being worth even more once fully finished. title: woman stays absolutely filthy hotel
story: Woman stays in absolutely filthy hotel with hole in wall and cracked windowsLeanne booked the Adelphi Hotel in Liverpool for her sister Libby and her partner as a surprise after working through the pandemic as a care worker - and says they were moved to another room that was just as badA woman has blasted the rooms at The Adelphi Hotel in Liverpool Image: Andrew Teebay Liverpool EchoByAaliyah RuggAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA woman who booked a surprise hotel stay for her sister and partner has been left horried at the room she was given.Leanne, who did not want her surname to be published, booked the Adelphi Hotel in Liverpool for her sister Libby and her partner for a surprise after working through the pandemic, the Liverpool ECHO reports. She says the roomaposs window was cracked and there was a hole in the ceiling with a bin underneath. Leanne told the ECHO: Me and my little sister have both worked right the way through the pandemic. She works days and I work nights and sheaposs been helping me look after my little boy. So to say thank you I wanted to book her and her partner a little getaway.  We live in Norfolk now but are from Liverpool and have family here so I thought it would be nice for them to come back to our home city. Originally I was going to book the Dolby hotel but I thought it would be out the way, so I changed my mind and booked the Adelphi instead because itaposs right in town and everything is close. She arrived on Monday and was put in one room but the window was all cracked and there was a hole in the ceiling with a bin under it. The bin was covered with water as though there had been a leak and was also covered with rubbish.  In the bathroom, the towel rail was off the wall and just sat on the floor. They went to complain and they were given another room which was smaller but just as bad. After complaining about the state of the second room, the couple were given a new room. Leanne added: The window was all cracked and the bed linen was so dirty. This was all on the first day and she was put in another room. I FaceTimed her that night and she didnapost look happy at all. Outside the room, there were holes in the ceiling.  I rang the hotel myself and the sht manager said he would sort another room out. They were taken to another floor and on the corridor, there were care packages left outside of doors which made her panic people were quarantining. The manager said thataposs just how they would do things now after Covid. Another thing they do because of Covid is use paper cups. So my sister went down to get a paper cup and was given one with a lid on.  When she got back to her room she took the lid off to use it and it was absolutely filthy. It was f*****g disgusting, just minging. She then went back to the main desk for a clean one and they apologised and said it must have gotten mixed up. How can it get mixed up when itaposs a paper cup and should be thrown straight in the bin. It looked like someone had just had soup out of it. Leanne says that despite several attempts to contact Britannia Hotels, who own the Adelphi Hotel, she has had no response to complaints made. She said: What was meant to be five nice, peaceful days away were just horric. It used to be a good hotel. Iaposve since been looking at the reviews and they all say what my sister went through. Itaposs disgusting. Thecontacted Britannia Hotels for a comment. Comment MORE ON Britannia Hotels Ltd." data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman who refused covid jab
story: Exclusive: Woman who refused Covid jab begged doctors to save her before she died EIGHT timesGemma Roberts, from Warrington, in Cheshire, sorely regrets refusing to get the jab before she caught coronavirus and suffered eight cardiac arrests, with hero doctors bringing her back each timeGemma Roberts sorely regrets refusing to get the jab before she fell ill with Covid and is urging others not to make the same mistake Image: Gemma RobertsByMatthew DreschReporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov An unvaccinated woman who aposdiedapos eight times after being hospitalised with Covid has urged other Brits to get the jab. Gemma Robertsapos heart stopped repeatedly while doctors battled to save her le as she fought Covid and two bouts of sepsis.She now sorely regrets refusing to get the jab before she fell ill - and said she is only alive today thanks to the medical staff at Warrington Hospital. The -year-oldaposs ordeal began when she was rushed to hospital in August and placed on a ventilator, which she stayed on for two months. She told The Mirror: I remember saying to doctors and nurses aposplease donapost let me dieapos.Before I was put to sleep I rang my partner Sophie and said aposthey are having to put me to sleep but Iaposm going to be okayapos.  But there were moments when I thought aposI could be a goner hereapos. I wish I had the vaccine before, I think everyone should have it now. I was one of those people that was scared of having the jab. I heard it had killed people.I took a chance and I almost didnapost pull through. Medical professionals saved my le, thataposs who I will listen to now. I feel guilty because of what I put my family through with them not knowing whether I was going to wake up. Gemma said she is eternally grateful to one of her nurses, Collette Thomas, who told her throughout that she was going to survive. She said it from the start. I knew in my head she couldnapost make that promise but it comforted me at the time, Gemma said.The former Eddie Stobart worker, who was due to start a new job when she fell ill, also fought off two bouts of sepsis in hospital. Her partner Sophie Holmes, , said it sparked a rash across her body which left her aposlooking like she had been scoldedapos. Gemmaaposs ordeal began at the start of August when a Covid lateral flow test came back positive, with a subsequent PCR test confirming the result. At first I thought it was just a hangover as I had been at a wedding the weekend before. But then I tested positive, she said.  I was feeling tired and sick at the beginning and then I started to feel out of breath when I went to the toilet.When they said they were taking me into hospital I thought they would give me a bit of oxygen and let me out again.Iaposve got no underlying health conditions and it is the first time Iaposve been in hospital. Sophie said paramedics rushed her partner of one year to hospital after she rang  on August . She added: They put her on a CPAP machine and on the th they said they were going to put her to sleep as her oxygen wasnapost good enough. Thataposs when everything went crazy. On the th she had a cardiac arrest. Her heart stopped and she required CPR and resuscitation. They brought her back. A week later she had another one and was brought back again. She then had a couple of days before the next one. On August  she had four cardiac arrests. She had been ventilated for three weeks by that point. She had one more cardiac arrest after that. The longest period she was dead for was  minutes. Each time the doctors performed CPR and brought her back to me, I couldnapost ask for more. We were unvaccinated and have no underlying health conditions, we are just a bit chubby - thataposs it. The doctors saved her le.I want people to know not to believe the anti-vaxxer rubbish. We were brainwashed. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Gemma was finally taken off her ventilator at the start of October. When she awoke she was unable to move her arms and legs, but the hospital physio team have now got her back on her feet and she is able to walk with a zimmer frame. Her recovery is progressing quickly and she is looking forward to being discharged from hospital in the near future. She is also now set to marry support worker Sophie, who proposed to her a few days after she woke up.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Coronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news us-news drivers-scoop-up-wads-cash-"Tiktok CahsByKit RobertsMatthew DreschReporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsDrivers jumped out of their cars to scavenge wads of cash after the doors of an armoured truck flew open while it was transporting money. The extraordinary scene was caught on camera as the helpless truck driver resorted to filming those snatching the cash. TikTok users also recorded themselves taking free money off the road and throwing it in the air, while cheering with excitement.Police later arrived at the scene and arrested two people who locked themselves out of their car during the frenzy, the Daily Star reports. The truck had been on the interstate motorway in Carlsbad in the US at around am when one of the doors reportedly popped open, spilling bags of cash into the road. Fitness influencer Demi Bagby, who has . million followers online, filmed the incident on her phone. This is the most insane thing Iaposve ever seen, she said. Someone dropped money all over the freeway - San Diego has shut down. Literally it has shut down, look at the freeway right now, oh my gosh. Police confirmed that they have made two arrests in connection with the incident, with the Calornia Highway Patrol saying that videos on social media show several people stopping to pick up the cash. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter CHP Sergeant Curtis Martin said: There is a lot of video evidence of people picking up the cash, so we are going to be following up on every lead that we have. We did arrest two suspects on the scene. Those two suspects accidentally locked their car so it was blocking lanes of traffic, so they were still here when officers got here, so theyaposre in custody. The exact quantity of money that was dropped onto the highway is not clear at present, and a police investigation is ongoing. Meanwhile, the San-Diego Union-Tribune reported that at least a dozen people had reportedly ed the cash they had picked up to the CHP.
