title: from our files november 19 2021
story: Alan Read MP for Argyll and Bute spoke against the government on Tuesday whenAnd he called for Kintyre to be included in the fuel discount scheme planned for the islands.Mr Reid was speaking in a House of Commons debate on fuel prices on Tuesday,#The price of fuel adds to the price of everything in a rural area. The high cost isHe also welcomed government plans for a p per litre fuel duty discount on all theThat reduction will go part of the way towards removing the price dferential between fuel on the islands and fuel on the mainland.#I am sure that the pilot scheme for the islands will be successfulit is, I would like#I represent a sparsely populated constituency so I am well aware of the impact of#For example, the price of fuel on some of the larger islands in my constituency, such#This is not because of profiteering. The reasons for the higher prices are low turnover, compared to all the fixed costs that a rural filling station has to pay, and the costs of the distribution network.#TWENTY FIVE YEARS AGOSouth Kintyre cousins, Hendrie Barbour and John Galbraith ed home this weekHendrie and John were just two of , runners who took part in last weekend’s race, managing to clock up times of three hours  minutes  seconds and three hoursThe cousins, who decided to compete around last Christmas, had to have their entryAs non-Americans they also had to go through one of several special tour companies in order to obtain their places.For the sum of £ they gotflights, entry to the race, and a huge pasta dinner#There were two million Americans out lining the route on Sunday and all of themThe race was John’s first marathon and Hendrie#s second, but both of them nowFIFTY YEARS AGOSeven people, including a nine-month-old baby, were adrt for nearly an hour in stormy seas off Islay at the weekend after a Dutch coaster developed a bad list.The vessel, Regina, was on route from Port Rush to Benbecula with a cargo ofCaptain John Machers gave the order to abandon ship and sent out a Mayday call which sent out the Islay leboat.The survivors were thrown a rubber raft from the ,-ton freighter CP AmbassadorAs the raft was being hauled through the heavy seas, however, the line snapped and seven people were cast adrt.The Islay leboat, commanded by Coxswain Donald McPhee, reached the raft in just under an hour later after a -mile steam from Port Askaig to the scene.They were landed at Port Askaig and given warm food and clothing before being flown to Glasgow for the first part of their journey home.The baby, tiny Vanessa Machers, the captain’s daughter, was none the worse for herThe original Mayday message was intercepted by the watchman at Southend Coastguard Station and Islay leboat was advised to standby before the officialThe rescue operation itself was controlled by Southend Coastguards. CoastguardsA Royal Navy lorry loaded with six tons of explosives left the road and nearlyThe lorry, which was on its way from RAF Machrihanish to Glen Douglas, caught theUS Navy officials rushed to the scene and Campbeltown police were kept busyA no smoking ban was imposed until the lorry was pulled back onto the road by a mobile crane.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOThe recently formed branch of An Comunn Gaidhealach Ceannloch in CampbeltownThere was a remarkably large attendance, the hall being filled by an audience thatA Highland gathering has an atmosphere all of its own and this meeting lackedSherf Macmaster Campbell, the hon President, was in the chair. He explained thatThe address of the evening was delivered by the Rev Donald Macfarlane, Gigha, whoA new call office has been opened at Machrihanish Sub-Post Office .The fee for the use of the call office will be d, and it will be connected with any

title: goalkeeper imogen lands regional squad position
story: The Campbeltown Grammar School pupil will receive coaching and will form the nucleus of the first team of the Scottish Schools# Football Association West Regional squad which will play inter-area matches during season  .It is believed that Imogen is the first girl from Campbeltown ever to be selected, and possibly the first player since .Campbeltown Pupils s coach and Campbeltown and District Juvenile Football Associationchairman Rhys Blair said: #I am immensely proud of Imogen. She is a valued member of the U age group and I am gutted that this is Imogen#s last season with the youth team as she is a very talented goalkeeper.#CDJFA secretary Claire Mitchell, who nominated Imogen for the opportunity, said: #I am absolutely delighted for Imogen and I believe this is just the beginning for her.#I have been aware for sometime that this is Imogen#s last season playing with Campbeltown Pupils U and I knew we had to do something to get her talent recognised as things couldn#t end there for her.#When I heard about the trials, I knew this was the first step for Imogen and I knew she could do it.#We wish Imogen all the best we know she will do brilliantly but, most importantly, we want her to have fun.#Imogen#s parents Rosemary and Robert added: #We are are extremely proud of Imogen, she deserves this and more. She has always kept her feet firmly on the ground. Keep being you, Imogen!#Imogen thanked everyone for all their support and comments on her success and Claire for nominating her.The West Regional team will be taking part in an inter-district tournament at Toryglen Regional Football Centre, Glasgow, next Friday, November , with a .pm kick-off.

title: leader november 19 2021
story: Rarely does something taken up as a teenage hobby or interest turn into a le-long career but that was the case for Campbeltown#s David Cox and his love of the sea.David has devoted almost  years to the town#s leboat station and it will be strange when he#s no longer there.Repeatedly risking his own le to rescue others in peril at sea, David has taken all the many challenges of his role in his stride.The final  months of his tenure have been particularly challenging as the crew had to adopt new ways of operating to maintain their own safety while rescuing others amid the Covid- pandemic.Living on a peninsula, many Kintyre residents work at sea and even more of us frequent the water for ious leisure pursuits, safe in the knowledge that people like David are little more than a phone-call awaydisaster strikes.We hope David enjoys his well-earned retirement, and is able to spend more time with his family.And we wish Ruaridh McAulay, who replaces David as coxswain, all the best in his new position.

title: letters november 19 2021
story: I write with regard to your front page news in the Campbeltown Courier dated November .While the completion of the Beinn an Tuirc  windfarm and its contribution to providing clean energy is to be welcomed, the lack of provision for the local communities by Scottish Power Renewablesand Amazon is not.The Scottish Government’s  document Good Practice Principles for Shared Ownership of Onshore Renewable Energy Developments states: #Shared ownership can help promote stronger relationships between local communities and the renewables sector, and deliver lasting economic and social benefits to communities across Scotland.#It continues to be our view that successful renewable energy projects will be those, which treat communities as active and positive partners, and we expect to see engagement for all scales of development above microgeneration.#Unfortunately Scottish Power Renewableshas failed to deliver SharedFor the last two years, East Kintyre Renewable Energy Grouphas been negotiating tirelessly with SPR on behalf of Campbeltown, East and West Kintyre Community Councils, only to be given an offer which,taken up, would make little commercial sense.The independent financial consultants QMPF stated that ‘the offer being made by SPR does not meet the definition of shared ownership per the Scottish Government definition’.As a consequence, now that the construction phase at Beinn an Tuirc  is completed, little of the profits from this windfarm will benefit Kintyre.The Scottish Government wants to secure an additional - GW of installed onshore wind capacity by . It is seeking views on how to secure maximum economic benefit from these developments.It would be helpfulKintyre residents made their views known, responding to the consultation and requesting that the Scottish Government: make community benefit funding and community shared ownership respect landscape capacity requirements that restrict turbine size andI have been hearing from many of my constituents across the Kintyre and the Islands ward about the need for long term road repairs on many of Argyll and Bute Council#s roads.There is no doubt that recent investment is a huge step in the correct direction and full resurfacing is preferable to a patchwork quilt of odd repairs of our older roads.We all know that just about every road gets potholes at some point. Whether it’s from age, bad weather, or the road was paved poorly to begin with, potholes show up.As with most things in le, they can be fixed the right wayor the wrong way, meaning they quickly open up again.Repairing potholes quickly and correctly is important because it prevents further degradation of the road.It seems easy enough to just fill in the open hole in the road or carpark with new tarmac, but this actually is just a temporary stop-gap. The pothole will almost certainly reappear, and the area between the old tarmac and new tarmac will become the weakest part of the road.Our hardworking and at times thinly-stretched front line road men do a terric job but they like all departments are limited by what funding they receive, as is the wider council.As your local councillor I will continue to build on past success in lobbying for more infrastructure investment and will do my upmost to make sure that no road is left behind.While I can#t guarantee success, I can guarantee that I will be relentless in my pursuit of a better deal for our local ward and the wider Argyll and Bute constituency.As we pause to remember the fallen on Remembrance Day our thoughts naturally turn to the veterans of the Second World War, rightly so.This stoic and humble generation made the ultimate sacrice and have been an inspiration for the countless servicemen and women who have followed after them.We must also remember those who answered their country’s call to serve more recently in campaigns in the Middle East, and Europe.Events in Afghanistan this year reminded us all, not least those who had served there and their families, that for those who do their duty, duty does not end when they arrive home.For many, the physical and mental impact of their service remains with them for the rest of their lives.Our mission at the fund is to find all those who did their duty, however long ago, and ensure they know we are here for them, as long as they need us.In celebration of their service, we are calling on members of the public to share their loved ones’ stories as part of our Month to Remember. Go to lovedonesmissed.memorypage.org dedication to pay tribute to your family members.

title: photograph of the week november 19 2021
story: The stunning picture was taken from the Port Wemyss coastal path looking towards the lighthouse which is situated on the small island of Orsay off the south coast of Islay.If you have a photograph you would like to share, please email it to editor@campbeltowncourier or send it via the Courier#s Facebook page.

title: pupils u15s lose out after leading in first half
story: After leading for most of the first half, Campbeltown Pupils slost out to second-in-the-league Westercommon Stars in a home fixture last Sunday.The teams paid their respects to Remembrance Sunday with a minute#s silence before the Glasgow and District Youth Football Leaguematch on the G all-weather pitch at Kinloch Green.The first half of the game saw a strong Campbeltown side going - up with an equaliser just before half-time.The second half started slow for the home side and Westercommon took full advantage of the situation to make the full-time result -.#We have now played the top half of the table and we hope the Us have found their groove,# said coach Rhys Blair. #We are positive they can start picking up points and climb the table.#

title: rhunahaorine remembers
story: As part of a Remembrance display in the playground, the children painted poppies on scallop shells.Although most poppies were red, some children chose white to represent peace and some chose purple to remember animals who were killed in service.There were also small wooden crosses which the children had previously taken home so they could write the names of any relatives they wanted to remember.Many of these crosses had been kept from previous years as this has now become an annual event at the school.On Thursday November , everyone in the school gathered outside for a short service to which parents could unfortunately not be invited due to an increase in Covid case numbers in Kintyre.Pupil Kieran Hurd read a verse from the Bible which was followed by a verse from For the Fallen by poet Laurence Binyon.The school chaplain, Marilyn Shedden, said a prayer after which all stood silently.Morvern Paisley then played a moving rendition of The Last Post on her flute.Finally, two large wreaths and an acrylic representation of a soldier were placed at the front of the table.All children and staff walked past the display before ing to the classroom.#Normally the table is left up for the whole day but by lunch time the wind had come up after the lovely morning so we rushed out and carefully boxed all of the crosses and wreaths for next year,# said head teacher Catriona Brown.

title: thought for the week november 19 2021
story: To pray such a request is to recognise that all is not as it should be, that Divine intervention and human cooperation go together.Why should God ask us to pray and therefore to be involved – can’t He just do stuff without us Well yes, He can and does – but history and scripture teach that He also works through our prayers – #Your kingdom come your will be done on earth as it is in heaven# is a submission to desire Christ’s Kingship over our lives and over the world. What does it look like day by day The rule and reign of God is seen when human beings love.#For He who loves His fellow man has fulfilled the law….. Love does no harm to its neighbour, therefore, love is the fulfilment of the law.# .To believe by faith that this ever-expanding cosmos has at the beginning and the end, an all-powerful God is to believe that this God is bigger than it all. He is the Alpha and Omega, that is the A and the Z.#He is before all things and in Him all things hold together#. Col : – The final destiny of the planet is in His hands but meanwhile we are stewards of the planet He has given us. On it we are to love our neighbour. What does that look like for you  Love makes us think of other people#s needs not just our own. His Kingdom come His will be done.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: east-lothian-foodbank-takes-step-pay-living-wage
story: Everyone working at the foodbank, on Civic Square in Tranent, will receive a minimum hourly wage of pound..In Scotland, more than  per cent of jobs pay less than the real Living Wage.A foodbank spokesperson said they were committed to paying the real Living Wage and delivering a ldquofair dayrsquos pay for a hard dayrsquos work.Employers choose to pay the real Living Wage on a voluntary basis.Elaine Morrison, East Lothian Foodbank manager, said: ldquoWe would like to live in a society where food charity is not needed, where everybody has a job that pays them a living wage and a social security system that means those who are not able to work are supported adequately without the need for foodbanks.ldquoBeing able to earn a living wage is key to this.ldquoWe are committed to achieving this for the empowerment and betterment of our team and to ensure that they know that the work they do in what can be a very challenging environment is valued.ldquoWe are incredibly proud to be a Living Wage employer and would encourage more local organisations to sign up to the Living Wage and help us move towards a more independent and sustainable community.Peter Kelly, The Poverty Alliance director, said: ldquoToo many workers in Scotland are in the grip of poverty and employers choosing to pay at least the real Living Wage can loosen that grip.ldquoCongratulations to East Lothian Foodbank on their Living Wage commitment and I hope more organisations follow their lead by becoming Living Wage accredited.

title: east-lothian-covid-19-hotspots-revealed
story: East Lothian recorded  cases of Covid- between November  and .This gives a seven-day positive rate per , people of ..This is slightly higher than the figures between November  and . During that time period,  positive Covid- cases were recorded, a seven-day positive rate per , people of ..There have been no deaths involving Covid- in East Lothian so far this month.Wallyford and Whitecraig recorded the most cases in East Lothian in the last seven days, , while the highest seven-day positive rate was in Dunbar East, with a current rate of ..Listed below is a breakdown of case numbers in each part of East Lothian:Meanwhile, the vast majority of East Lothian residents have now received both doses of a coronavirus vaccine.As of yesterday , , people over the age of  have received their first dose of a coronavirus vaccine.This equals . per cent of the population.A total of , people have received their second dose, or . per cent of the population.And , residents or . per cent have received a third dose or booster coronavirus vaccine.

title: saltire-festival-returns-east-lothian-busy-programme-events
story: Music, film, a market and a battlefield tour are just some of the events taking place during the Saltire Festival this year.The annual festival, which has run in East Lothian since , gets under way on November .Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism, was looking forward to the festival, which ends on St Andrewrsquos Day .He said: ldquoThe Saltire Festival has been a favourite fixture on East Lothianrsquos calendar for many years now and this yearrsquos programme has another great mix of events to appeal to all tastes ndash with a strong Scottish and East Lothian theme.ldquoTickets are selling fast so Irsquod advise being quick to avoid disappointment.ldquoI canrsquot wait to see the creative submissions coming in for our first Saltire social media competition too.ldquoItrsquos a great way to have a bit of fun and support local businesses by getting out and spending the East Lothian Gt Card prizes.ldquoKeep an eye on the website and Facebook page for any events that may be added to the programme in the next few weeks.A special screening of classic Scottish film Local Hero kicks off the festival at The Brunton.The Musselburgh venue also hosts Scottish folk singer songwriter Kris Drever on November , and Keith Jack and the McDonald Brothers perform songs from popular Scottish artists the following day.A free exhibition in The Brunton foyer throughout the month tells the story of Dunbar-born conservationist John Muirrsquos love of the work of Robert Burns.There is also a chance to tour the site of the Battle of Prestonpans on November  alongside battlefield historian Dr Arran Johnston, while a Saltire-themed farmersrsquo market takes place in Haddington on November .To celebrate the Saltire Festival, a competition is running on Instagram and Twitter.Entrants should take a photo of themselves at their favourite East Lothian landmark wearing something Scottish, post it on social media and tag East Lothian Council using #SaltireFest ndash the top three submissions will receive a pound East Lothian Gt Card.Entries are to be submitted by St Andrewrsquos Day, with the winners announced on December .For more information, go to saltirefestival

title: businesses-haddington-set-light-windows-christmas-competition
story: Haddington Business Community Partnershipis hosting a lsquoLight up your window for Christmasrsquo competition.Festive decorations and Christmas lights will adorn shop windows by November  ndash the day before the townrsquos Christmas lights switch-on.Judging will take place on November  after am to decide a winner.Karla Green, chairperson of HBCP, wished everyone well and said: ldquoLast yearrsquos competition was highly competitive, with some wonderful displays, and the judge found it extremely dficult to pick a winner.ldquoThis year there will be the HBCP challenge trophy, a second and a third rosette, and an outstanding achievement trophy.The window competition comes on the heels of lsquoHaddowersquoenrsquo, which was sponsored by Haddington Rotary.Kodak Express, on the townrsquos Market Street, took top prize, with MADE in East Lothian and Animal Magic coming second and third respectively.

title: john-swinney-apologises-booster-vaccine-rollout-issues-east-lothian-issue-raised-holyrood
story: A bus, launched by East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership , was to be used as a drop-in service in rural areas.In the first four days of its operation, more than  people attended the bus, which provides Covid- boosters and flu jabs for lsquopriority groupsrsquo ndash but problems have already been encountered.People faced y queues in Gullane and had to wait for hours to receive their booster vaccine.Further complications were experienced in Dunbar, as the drop-in arrangements were scrapped in favour of appointments only. That saw some residents in need of a booster being turned away.Craig Hoy, South Scotland MSP, highlighted the problems at First Ministerrsquos Questions in Holyrood.Mr Hoy said: ldquoMy constituent Norma from Dirleton received her booster vaccine some time ago, but yesterday received a fourth letter calling out for a jab. She has been unable to cancel the appointment.ldquoBut her -year-old neighbour has received no vaccine booster correspondence and she too has faced problems getting through on the appointment line.ldquoAnd despite attending a mobile vaccine bus twice last Thursday in Gullane, she had to leave due to theof the queues.ldquoSo will the Deputy First Minister urgently look into the ongoing problems in the vaccine booster scheme across the Lothians Deputy First Minister John Swinney offered an apology to those who had suffered issues with the booster programme in East Lothian and admitted that ldquothey should never have experienced that.The SNP minister said: ldquoThere have been a number of issues in relation to NHS Lothian in connection with the appointments system, with which we are familiar.ldquoOur officials met with the chief executive of NHS Lothian earlier this week to discuss these very practical issues which Mr Hoy raises with me.Some over-s and immunosuppressed residents of the county have been asked to wait until mid-December to receive their booster vaccine in East Lothian, despite previously receiving assurances that they would receive their jab by the middle of November, and many others have yet to receive any booster appointment at all.Following the meeting, Mr Hoy said: ldquoI am glad that John Swinney has admitted that there are issues with the booster programme in East Lothian.ldquoSadly, that wonrsquot come as news to the many East Lothian residents who have contacted me in the past few weeks about the problems they have faced.ldquoIt was correct that he apologised to East Lothian residents for this as it simply hasnrsquot been good enough.ldquoBut residents need action and not hollow words from ministers.Pat Wynne, nurse director of primary and community care, NHS Lothian, said: ldquoEast Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership and NHS Lothian apologise to patients who have been inconvenienced by changes made to the timetable for the vaccine bus and we would like to assure patients that these decisions are not taken lightly.ldquoTo date, across Lothian over , boosters and , flu vaccines have been delivered.ldquoAlongside our partners, we apologise to patientsthey have been kept waiting either at a clinic or for an appointment and reassure them that we are doing everything possible to address any issues that have been identied.ldquoThis is a highly complex and fast-paced programme which is being managed alongside the continued rollout of both first and second doses of the Covid vaccine.ldquoAppointment letters for any remaining people aged  and over who were due either their flu vaccine, their booster or both vaccines recently landed on doorsteps across Lothian, with appointments taking place during the last two weeks in November. The final group of invite letters for those aged - will be issued this week, with appointments taking place during November and December.ldquoThe national online booking portal for those aged -, unpaid and young carers, and household contacts of immunosuppressed iniduals opened on Monday, with appointments across Lothian being available to book. Patients are being urged to keep their appointment once booked, butthey cannot attend they can reschedule by calling the national vaccination helpline on   .

title: north-berwick-charity-shares-findings-global-beach-clean-survey-cop26
story: Fidrarsquos Great Global Nurdle Hunt  ndash the third it has carried out ndash comes off the back of the grouprsquos annual Great Nurdle Hunt, launched in .And results from the survey, which discovered millions of tiny plastic pellets on beaches throughout the world, were revealed at the global conference last Tuesday.Fidra was launched by Dr Becky Gait ndash formerly of North Berwick and now living in Australia ndash in , when she brought together a group of parents and friends with a shared passion for the environment and expertise in science, public health, law and finance.The group launched the Great Nurdle Hunt to document nurdle pollution and engage with industry and others.The charity is now run by a team of nine, and four trustees, out of an office on North Berwickrsquos Westgate.In this yearrsquos Great Global Nurdle Hunt,  out of  of the countries that took part found the pellets, known as nurdles, on their coastline.Megan Kirton, from Fidra, said: ldquoCOP is a real opportunity to highlight pellet pollution to international decision-makers and we canrsquot thank all our volunteers enough for helping us show that this is a widespread global pollution issue that needs action now.ldquoWe canrsquot keep using energy and fossil fuels to make plastic that ends up in the environment. Nurdle pollution demonstrates plastic is being wasted before it has even been used to make anything.And the response from delegates and members of the public at COP to the grouprsquos findings showed the importance of raising the issue, with some not having heard of nurdles before.Megan said: ldquoWe were presenting the findings from this yearrsquos Great Global Nurdle Hunt at our information stall in the Green Zone of COP.ldquoThe results were well received ndash we spoke to many interested members of the public, academics, NGOs and delegates about the pellet pollution issue.ldquoMany had not heard of nurdles or this pellet pollution issue before, so this opportunity helped us raise the profile of the issue and recruit more nurdle hunters from around the world.More than  volunteers spent a total of  hours last month scouring beaches for the tiny microplastic pellets.Volunteers racked up a total of  hunts during October, with millions of nurdles estimated to be found in some of the worst hotspots surveyed.Nurdles are small round pellets produced by the plastics industry and melted down to make nearly all plastic products.Once produced in plastic manufacturing plants, nurdles are shipped and couriered to multiple destinations before they are made into a plastic product. At each stage of transport and handling, nurdles can be spilled into the environment.Among those taking part in the survey was Melissa Nel, a volunteer co-ordinator and research assistant for the Orca Foundation in South Africa.She found more than , nurdles in two days while participating in the event.Melissa said: ldquoAfter seeing the Fidra nurdle movement, we decided to focus our beach clean-ups on nurdle collecting.ldquoAbout one year ago, nurdles started washing up in huge numbers along Plettenberg Bayrsquos beaches and there has been a huge community drive to help assist in the nurdle problem ndash which has been amazing.ldquoBut there is still a lot of work to do.ldquoIt is the worst of times, but it is the best of times because we still have a chance to make a dference.

title: knox-academy-pupils-ditching-school-uniforms-support-children-need
story: Children in Need will be marked at the secondary school with a dress down day.Sue Cook, headteacher at the Haddington school, noted that more than pound was raised at the school for the good cause last year.She said: ldquoOur senior pupils will be lsquodressing uprsquo in a iety of fun costumes and organising a bake sale.ldquoThis day is always a lot of fun at school, as we come together as a school community to support a great cause ndash it is also great for everyonersquos morale.ldquoIt also links directly with our school vision of lsquokindnessrsquo and value of lsquocommunityrsquo.

title: tales-myths-sea-storytelling-session-port-seton
story: Port Seton Library hosts childrenrsquos author Annemarie Allen, who will share her latest novel and lead a myths of the sea family poetry writing session in celebration of Book Week Scotland.To book a place, email aslibraries@eastlothian.gov.uk or call   and ask for Port Seton Library.

title: adventurous-grandmother-taking-desert-trek-jordan
story: Bronwyn Brodie travels to Jordan tomorrowas one of more than a dozen walkers raising money and awareness for Maggiersquos.Together, they will walk  kilometres ndash  miles ndash through the Wadi Rum, also known as the Valley of the Moon, in aid of the charity, which supports those affected by cancer.Looking ahead to the trip, which has been in the pipeline for more than a year, Bronwyn said: ldquoI am super excited but a little nervous because it is the unexpected.ldquoI feel asI know the trekkers only because we have got a Whats-App group and we have had a few Zoom-type calls.ldquoEverybody that is doing the trek is raising funds, not necessarily for Maggiersquos Edinburgh but other Maggiersquos. My money is going to Maggiersquos Edinburgh.Already, Bronwyn, who works with youngsters with additional support needs at Musselburgh Grammar School, has raised more than pound, for the good cause.The walkers, who come from throughout Britain, will wild camp and complete the memorable experience in just four days.The grandmother-of- told the Courier how Maggiersquos had impacted her le after she was diagnosed with breast cancer in .She underwent surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy but it was not until she was undergoing treatment that she visited the Maggiersquos Centre at Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital.Bronwyn, of Dunbar, said: ldquoThey are just such a wonderful place and the feeling you get when you go in is like in a sanctuary.ldquoYou can speak to somebody, one of the staff or they have volunteers in there.ldquoYou can chat to people or you can sit and just be yourself.ldquoIt is whatever you want but my family, the first time they went in there, they also felt this overwhelming serenity.The visit soon became Bronwynrsquos ldquopassion and she has since taken part in two Culture Crawls ndash Maggiersquos flagship fundraising event.In January last year, she spotted the chance to raise money and awareness for the charity through a -kilometre trek through the Sahara Desert.The incredible experience was due to take place in November last year but was shelved due to the coronavirus pandemic.It was then pushed back again before finally the organisers were forced to move it from Morocco and the Sahara Desert to Jordan and Wadi Rum.Bronwyn, who is mum to Douglas, Darren, Ceinwyn and Lesley, will finish the trek in Petra.She said: ldquoIt is still a desert but it is a dferent kind of desert.ldquoIt is more rocky in parts but it is still a desert and the ultimate goal is still to raise funds and awareness for Maggiersquos.To support Bronwyn and Maggiersquos, go to justgiving fundraising bronwyn-brodie

title: msps-praise-amazing-work-east-lothian-foodbank
story: East Lothian Foodbank, on the townrsquos Civic Square, was set up in  and is part of the Trussell Trust network.Since opening, it has handed out more than , food parcels, with ,kg of donations feeding , adults and , children.Craig Hoy, a South Scotland MSP and councillor for the Haddington and Lammermuir ward, visited the foodbank recently and saw first-hand the work being carried out.He thanked everyone connected with the organisation for ldquoall of the amazing support they provided to people in the county.Mr Hoy said: ldquoLast year, the foodbank supported over , people, including nearly , children.ldquoItrsquos an outstanding community service which has been critical for many families in East Lothian during the Covid pandemic.Elaine Morrison, manager of East Lothian Foodbank, encouraged people to get in touch.She said: ldquoOver the next three years wersquoll be working to implement our new strategy, continuing to work with, and for, our community to ensure that people without enough money for food are able to access emergency support whilst also exploring ways to reduce the need for our service.

title: good-beer-guide-2022-see-9-east-lothian-pubs-made-list
story: Published by CAMRA, the  release marks the th edition recommendingthousands of places for a pint in regions across the country, alongside detailed descriptionsof the pub and often examples of the beers onoffer.Each venue in the book has been visited by an expert volunteer, who consider both the beer on offer as well as atmosphere and location.Heres what you need to know about the East Lothian pubs and breweries that feature in The Good Beer Guide ...Volunteer Arms - Dunbar Victoria Street, EH HPLocated near the harbour, this traditional pub serves two real ales which are usually from smallerbreweries, while the upstairs restaurant offers great seafood.Tweeddale Arms Hotel - GfordHigh Street, EH QUYou can choose from a range of rooms to enjoy your pint at the Tweeddale Arms Hotel.Bonnie Badger - GullaneMain Street, EH ABThe Bonnie Badger serves three changing beers which can be sipped while playing a game of pool or alongside a bar meal.Old Clubhouse - GullaneEast Links Road, EH AFThis pub looks over the golf links and the Lammermuir hills, with a good reputation for food, wine and beer.Waterside Bistro - Haddington- Waterside, EH ATLocated by the river, the Waterside Bistro is described as a great place for an outdoor drink.Levenhall Arms - Musselburgh Ravensheugh Road, EH PPThis th century pub is located near the race course and is a good spot for a game of dominoes and watching live sport.Volunteer Arms- Musselburgh North High Street, EH JEHaving been in the same family since , this was a Local CAMRA Pub of the Year , offeringa traditional snug and bar and more modern lounge.Auld Hoose - North Berwick Forth Street, EH HXAuld Hoose offers traditional Scottish hospitality with a modern twist and live music on a regular basis.Nether Abbey Hotel - North Berwick Dirleton Avenue, EH BQFour changing beers can accompany a meal from the award winning restaurant at Nether Abbey Hotel.Ship Inn - North Berwick- Quality Street, EH HJLocated in the town centre, the Ship Inn is described as being a "staple of East Lothian le" for many years.Mercat Bar and Grill - Whitecraig Whitecraig Road, EH PGThis award-winning, family run bar and restaurant welcomes everyone, from kids to dogs.The Good Beer Guide  is available to buyonline at the CAMRA shop.

title: inveresk-film-club-returns-following-easing-covid-restrictions
story: The first movie of the new season is The Dig, which will be shown at Inveresk Church Hall in Dalrymple Loan this eveningat pm.The British drama film, directed by Simon Stone, is based on the  novel of the same name by John Preston, based on the events of the  excavation of Sutton Hoo.It stars Carey Mulligan, Ralph Fiennes, Lily James, Johnny Flynn, Ben Chaplin, Ken Stott, Archie Barnes and Monica Dolan.The suggested donation is pound.

title: special-christmas-shopping-event-taking-place-farm-known-pumpkin-patch
story: Kilduff Farm, near Athelstaneford, is home to a pumpkin patch which specialises in culinary pumpkins as well as Hallowersquoen ieties.Now the Calder family ndash Lucy, her husband Russell and their three children ndash will inject some Christmas sparkle into their family farm.A festive shopping event will take place on December , kicking off with an early session from .pm until pm, followed by a later session from pm until .pm.Tickets cost pound, which will include access to the event and entry into a raffle supported by some of East Lothianrsquos top local producers.The evening is in support of RSABI ndash a charity providing emotional, practical and financial support to iniduals and their families across the agricultural sector.Lucy said: ldquoWersquore really looking forward to rounding off the year in such a special way.ldquoWe will welcome some of East Lothianrsquos finest makers, creators and producers to the farm and we would love people to join us for a mulled wine or a glass of festive fizz while looking for the perfect gt for friends and family.ldquo has been a dficult year for the East Lothian farming community, losing two well-respected and much-loved members in just a few days.ldquoWe have felt helpless in the aftermath of these devastating losses and there is so much unspoken mental suffering in farming.ldquoWe all need to support and raise awareness around the vital work RSABI does and this felt like an opportunity for us to do something for this worthwhile cause while remembering our friends at this particularly challenging time of year.Tickets are available to buy at www.kilduffThe evening event is open to over-s only.

title: family-hunt-9-000-nanny-look-twins-east-lothian-castle-christmas
story: The family will be spending December  to January  in an East Lothian castle with extended family and require a nanny for their five-year-old children.The location has not been disclosed.However, despite a salary of more than pound per day, there is a catch: the successful applicant will be unable to spend Christmas with their family.The nanny will be on duty  hours a day with a room adjoining the childrenrsquos.Responsibilities include dressing and washing the youngsters, as well as walks and outdoor activities.The nanny will also be in charge of reading and an evening routine, as well as ldquogenerally ensuring the children are entertained.Anyone looking to apply should have at least five years of experience and the nanny will be required to sign an NDA .Applicants must also be double-vaccinated against Covid-.To apply, go to jobsinchildcare job  experienced-nanny-for-twins-age--over-christmas-and-new-year-east-lothian

title: electronic-tag-mum-wrongly-claimed-27-000-benefits
story: Laura Reid was sentenced to a restriction of liberty order between the hours of pm and am when she appeared for sentencing at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Thursday.Reid, of Moir Avenue, Musselburgh, had previously admitted wrongly claiming working tax and child tax credits amounting to pound,.Reid had claimed the amount from the Department for Work and Pensions over a two-year period despite permanently living with her partner Joshua Allison, who was in full-time employment.The -year-old was paid the amount she was not entitled to between April , , and April , .Sherf Roderick Flinn had deferred sentence to last week for reports to be prepared and last week was told that Reid ldquowas making repayments of her own volition.Solicitor Euan Gosney said that his client was currently taking a part-time university course and worked at an after-school club.Mr Gosney said that Reid fully admitted the offence but that Mr Allison had not been staying at the family home ldquothe whole time.The sherf decided not to impose an unpaid work punishment as he believed that would ldquoimpact on her children and acknowledged the offence was ldquoout of character. He also relaxed the restriction of liberty order to pm to am on Tuesdays as that was when Reid attended her university course.Reid pleaded guilty to fraudulently obtaining working tax credits and child tax credits amounting to pound, between April , , and April , .

title: punk-covers-band-rock-dunbars-royal-british-legion-raise-money-venue
story: Setting Sons, who once supported punk legends Stf Little Fingers, performed at Dunbarrsquos Royal British Legion, with the money going towards paying for a Christmas party.Keith McCraw formed the band in  and they have gone on to play Glasgowrsquos Barrowlands, Edinburghrsquos Liquid Rooms and HMV Picture House.However, the Dunbar-based band are no strangers to their home town and playing for friends.The band comprises of Keith, bass player Grahame Smith, drummer Jamie Wishart and vocalist Jodie Russell.Keith and Grahameare two of the original members from nearly  years ago.Keith said: ldquoIt all just started with two mates playing guitar in the back of the Dolphin pub in Dunbar, then we got Nfy a bass to fill out the sound and then within a year we were on stage with Stf Little Fingers.ldquoAll a bit surrealhellip but we love our home crowds and love to raise cash for charities.Already, the band, who play tracks by artists ranging from The Jam and The Clash to the Sex Pistols and Stf Little Fingers, are turning their attention to next year.Keith, the bandrsquos frontman and guitarist, said: ldquoWe sell out all our gigs quite fast so itrsquos maybe a sign we need bigger venues.ldquoOur next gig is in The Mash House in Edinburgh on January  ndash thatrsquos a wee bit bigger and is selling fast already.ldquoThen wersquore in Musselburgh in February with ska outfit The Skababs.ldquoItrsquos all a bit crazy. Wersquore just four locals that love what we do ndash and it seems our fans do too.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-november-15-19-1996-1971-1921
story: years agolsquoELEVENTH-hour bid to block Muir statuersquo told the East Lothian Courier on November , .Over  Dunbar residents have joined a campaign to prevent a statue of John Muir being placed in the High Street outside the Town House.In only a week, Sarah Mason, a partner in the William Mason shoe shop on the High Street, collected six petitions with the names of  local people opposed to the planned monument.She has sent them to the Scottish Office, which is currently deciding whether to give the scheme planning permission.Miss Mason, who lives in a flat opposite the Town House, said: ldquoThe people of Dunbar just donrsquot want it.ldquoA statue would not be in keeping with the character of the High Street.ldquoThe Town House itself is a work of art.ldquoIf they want a statue, why not have it in the John Muir Country Park  years agoTWO homes in Tranent were damaged by fire, reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier on November , .Two Tranent families had to find alternative accommodation on Monday after fire damaged their homes.One went to stay with relatives, while the other was temporarily re-homed by the Town Council.On Monday at about pm, Mrs Janet Reid,  Ormiston Crescent West, became aware of the smell of smoke in her house and contacted the fire brigade.Firemen from Tranent broke into the house upstairs at No  occupied by Mr John Stuart to find flames coming through the door.They extinguished the blaze which caused a hole in the floor, enabling firemen to look into the house below.Both homes were extensively damaged by smoke. years agolsquoTHE Professorrsquos Love Storyrsquo was a headline in The Haddingtonshire Courier on November , .As will be seen from our advertising columns, Haddington folks are to have a rare treat on Wednesday next, when Sir J. M. Barriersquos play of ldquoThe Professorrsquos Love Story will be played by Mr Durward Lely, and his number one company, in the Corn Exchange.This play has been a great success on both sides of the Atlantic and the version being played by Mr Lely is the same as was recently produced by the late H.B. Irving, at the Savoy Theatre, London.The visit will be looked forward to with the keenest interest.

title: peter-antonelli-trial-accused-says-teenage-girl-wanted-to-go-off-her
story: Peter Antonelli, , said of the former pupil during his evidence at the High Court in Edinburgh: "She was very angry at ."He said: "I know we had some sexual contact after she was . It happened from time to time ndash always consensual."Antonelli, of Gullane, said that when the girl left school she had wanted him to split up with a woman and go off with her.During questioning by advocate depute Chris Fyffe, he agreed that the girl was vulnerable in her own way and added that she had had the potential to become a talented musician.Piano teacher Antonelli said that he and another girl with whom he said he had sexual relations when she was an older teenager did not publicise it. He told the court: "We kept it quiet."He denied that he had contacted her asking her where she was and whether she had been out with friends. He also denied there was a time when she was out with friends and he "kerb crawled" her.: Retired music teacher accused of abuse tells trial he had sexual relationship with teenage pupilAntonelli has denied a string of sex charges brought against him said to have occurred between  and  at schools in East Lothian and other locations.He originally faced  charges of indecent conduct, breach of the peace, indecent assault and rape. Prosecutors withdrew eight of them at the end of the Crown case.The trial before judge Jamie Gilchrist QC continues.

title: covid-booster-countries-vaccine-time-limit-travel
story: To travel to some countries, you must have received the secondCovid vaccine within a certain time limitprior to your visit, which range from -days to a year.With Covid jabs rolled out from late last year, it means that some people will already be barred from travelthey cannot provide proof of a booster jab.This dilemma has led to the NHS England Covid status app showing proof of the booster vaccine.This is currently under consideration in Scotland, as confirmed by Nicola Sturgeon on Tuesday.Here are the countries which have a time limit on vaccine status and what you need to know...IsraelTo travel to Israel, iniduals must have either had two doses of the Covid vaccine within  days prior to entry, or a booster dose no less than  days prior to entry.AustriaAustria has introduced a lockdown for non vaccinated people.You are considered "fully vaccinated"for -days from the date of your second or third dose of a vaccine recognised by the Austrian authorities.If you are not fully vaccinated and cannot prove recent recovery from COVID, you cannot enter hotels, restaurants, bars, nightclubs, theatres, concerts, cinemas and shops that do not sell essential items.CroatiaThere are dferent ways to enter Croatia.You must either:SwitzerlandFor travelto Switzerland, your vaccine status is valid for one year after the date of your last jab.You can enter Switzerland for any travel purposeyou are fully vaccinated and can show adequate proof that you received your last jab within a year.VietnamTo travel to Vietnam, people must either have proof of Covid vaccination within -months prior to travel or a certicate of recovery from COVID-, dated within -months before travel.

title: amazon-customers-wont-able-use-visa-credit-cards-2022
story: The change will come in from January , according to the company.Currently Amazon users can choose to pay viaVisa, Delta, Visa Electron, MasterCard, EuroCard, American Express, UK based Maestro and Solo card, with this including Visa credit cards.However, in an email to customers, the companyconfirmed it will stop accepting payments made using Visa credit cards issued in the UK "starting January  ".UK-issued Visa credit cards will no longer be accepted due to "the high fees Visa charges for processing credit card transactions".Customers will still be able to use debit cards, including Visa, and non-Visa credit cards.Meanwhile, Bloomberg has reported that Visa credit cards that have been issued outside UK will still be available for use.A spokesperson for Amazon said:"The cost of accepting card payments continues to be an obstacle for businesses striving to provide the best prices for customers."These costs should be going down over time with technological advancements, but instead they continue to stay high or even rise."As a result of Visarsquos continued high cost of payments, we regret that Amazon will no longer accept UK-issued Visa credit cards as of January  ."With the rapidly changing payments landscape around the world, we will continue innovating on behalf of customers to add and promote faster, cheaper, and more inclusive payment options to our stores across the globe."

title: edinburgh-christmas-market-2021-opening-dates-times
story: The pandemic may have put a halt to the annual markets last year, but this year they are due back in all their festive glory.Edinburghs markets are famous and see thousands of people flock to Princes Street Gardens to get in on the action.This year will be no dferent, so heres everything you need to know about the Edinburgh Christmas markets ...There are ious markets across the city, which have slightly dferent dates and opening times.The East Princes Street Gardensmarketwill open in the early afternoon ofSaturday November and run until Tuesday January , operating between the hours of am to pm.The George Street eventwill also open in early afternoon onSaturday November   and run until Tuesday January   from the hours of am to pm.The West Princes Street Gardensevent will open at lunchtime on Saturday November  and run until December .There are markets in three locations in Edinburgh.The West Princes Street Gardens Santas grottois accessible from The Mound, Princes Street and Kings Stables Road.The George Street ice rink will be situated just up the road on George Street, while the East Princes Street Gardens market can be accessed from Princes Street and Market Street.If you are attending the West Princes Street Gardens or East Princes Street Gardens markets, there is pay and display available onFrederick Street, George Street, Hanover Street and Waterloo Place.For the George Street market, pay and display parking is available onCharlotte Square, Frederick Street, George Street and Hanover Street.There are plenty of transport options to Edinburgh Christmas markets that dont require a car.Waverley train station is located within a -minute walk of all three markets, as is the Edinburgh bus station.AtWest Princes Street Gardens there will be a Santas Grotto, where you can buy tickets to attend the visit Santa for pound..The East Princes Street Gardens will feature numerous market stalls as well as the big wheel,a bar, a box office and information point and toilets.George Street will host an ice rink, three market stalls and a bar.

title: st-andrews-day-2021-bank-holiday-get-day-off
story: Officially, St Andrews Day is a bank holiday in Scotland however it doesnt necessarily mean we get a day off work...Heres everything you need to know...St Andrews Day was officially declared a bank holiday by the Scottish government in .However, banks are not required to close on November they do not want to.If  November occurs on a weekend, the bank holiday is moved to the following Monday.Despite being a bank holiday, employers are not actually required by law to give employees a holiday on the St Andrews Day bank holiday.Meanwhile, schools do not take St AndrewsDayoff meaning pupils are still required to go to school.This year St Andrews Day will fall on Tuesday November .On St Andrews Day, the saltire must be flown on all Scottish government buildings.Any celebrations tend to revolve around Scottish food and drink like haggis and whisky as well as traditionalmusic and dancing.After St Andrews Day, the next bank holidays in Scotland are as follows:

title: scotland-v-japan-tv-channel-kick-off-time-scotland-rugby-match
story: Last week the team played a dominant South African side who defeated Scotland - in their second win of the tournament.Meanwhile, the loss marked Scotlands first defeat of the series, having won both their previous matches against Tonga and Australia.They will look to resume this winning streak against Japan this weekend Scotland holdthe historical edge with six wins to one under their belts since .While it was Japan who proved triumphant in their last head to head in , this time Scotland has the home crowd behind them.As fans prepare to once again fill up the Edinburgh stadium, heres how you can tune into Scotland v Japan at home...The Scotland v Japan match will take place at Murrayfield on Saturday November at pm.It is Scotlands fourthand final game in the autumn series, which will take place throughout November.Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.Meanwhile, TalkSPORT has the radio rights, soyou dont fancy watching on Amazon Prime, you can listen there.. title: runs-scotland-investigation-scotlands-corridors-power-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive access to the people and organisationswith signicant influence over so many aspects of our lives.From the hundreds of secret lobbying meetings to who really runs Scotlands wind farms, whisky and media - the investigation will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two months here.Hundreds of meetings between Scottish ministers and multinationals, wealthy iniduals and other influentialorganisationswere left off the lobbying register in  due to loopholes in legislation, The Ferret can reveal.Analysis of Scottish Government ministersrsquoengagements in shows that meetings, potentially of key public interest, were not in the register, including those between ministers andcompaniesawarded multi-million poundUK and Scottish contracts to supply the NHS in the run-up to Covid-.Read the full scale of unrecorded discussions here.Professional lobbyists, including former politicians, advisors and a former minister have met with Scottish Government representatives on behalf of clients  times since March , The Ferret can reveal.Scotlandis home to dozens of public relations, think-tanks and consultancy firms, including several formed by or employing people who served in the upper echelons of government.Find out the whos who of professional lobbyists here.Questions have been raised over the power and influence of energycompaniesfollowing analysis by The Ferret revealing how key sectors dominate Scottish lobbying.The Ferretcategorisedorganisationsthat lobbied Scottish Government ministers since the register was introduced in  to increase transparency.Read the full exclusive analysis here.Bigbusinessincluding oil and renewable energy, farming, fishing, finance and whisky dominated Scotland Office ministersrsquo meetings last year, analysis by The Ferret has found.We looked at all external meetings logged in  by Alister Jack, Secretary of State forScotland, UK Government ministers for Scotland David Duguid and Iain Stewart, as well as Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, who was deputy Secretary of State until he resigned in May that year.Read the full report exclusively here.The number ofcompaniesregistered in tax havens investing in Scotland over the last decade has increased by nearly  per cent.Analysis of Scottish Governmentdataby The Ferret found that in  there were  firms registered in the Cayman Islands, Bermuda and British Virgin Islands operating, compared to  in . Their collective turnover last year amounted to just over poundbn.Read the full exclusive story here.Nearly a third of Scotlandrsquos biggest wind farms have owners with links to offshore tax havens in the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Guernsey and Jersey.An investigation by The Ferret has also revealed that  of the largest  wind farms are ultimately ownedoutwithScotland in England, Spain, France, Germany, Norway, China and where.Read the full report here.Nearly  per cent of malt whisky distilleries are ultimately owned bycompaniesoutside Scotland with wealthy people linked to the industry including a French fashion billionaire, an Australian yoghurt tycoon, a Swiss philanthropist and Thailandrsquos richest man.The Ferret can reveal that of the Scots distilleries only a thirdare owned by Scottish firms.Read the full story here.Ten of Scotlands major newspapers are owned by just three men: Rupert Murdoch, Lord Rothermere and Frederick Barclay. They are all billionaires who, personally or through their businesses, have used thelawto avoid paying tax.An analysis by The Ferret reveals that all but one of Scotlands national newspapers, the Sunday Post, are owned in other countries.Read the full storyhereFive privatecompanieswho employ around three quarters of the workforce in Scotlandrsquos arms industry had thousands ofclosed doormeetings with the UK Government between  and .As part of TheFerretrsquosWho Runs Scotlandinvestigation we looked at firmsoperating in Scotlandrsquosdefenceindustry and examined data about them obtained by the Campaign Against Arms Trade .Read the full report here.The chief executives of quangos appointed by Scottish Government ministers were paid over poundm in total last year, leading to ldquoexcessive pay gaps between those at the top and lower paid public sector workers, The Ferret has found.In the course of ourresearchwe looked at the salaries ndash before bonuses or pension tops-up ndash of  leaders of quangos . There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish governmentpublic andhealthbodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotlandrsquos public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.Read the full story here.Influential bankers,retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotlandrsquos quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotlandrsquos public bodies.Some roles are unpaid, and manyworkextra hours intheirdevotion to public service. But analysis by The Ferret of Scottish Government public board positionshas also found a web of influential connections binding many serving in the public sector.Read the full analysis here.So who runs Scotland  Thatrsquos been the central question of The Ferret and The Heraldrsquos week-long investigation.Along the way wersquove examined the corridors of power and looked at who gets the most access to ministers ndash and who doesnrsquot.Find out the top most influential people in Scotland here.Scotlandrsquos biggest private landowner has been attacked as ldquomanipulative and ldquoundemocratic after The Ferret revealed that his company lobbied the Scottish Government to stymie plans for a spaceport in Sutherland.A letter released under freedom of informationlawshows thatWildland Limitedmdash which runs three large estates acrossScotlandfor Danish billionaire,Anders Holch Povlsenmdash warned the former ruraleconomyminister, Fergus Ewing, that its planned investments could be endangered by the spaceport.Read the full story here.Scotlandneeds a radical sht in the way that power and influence are distributed to help address democratic deficits and rebuild trust in the political process, The Ferret has been told.Politicians and campaigners reacting to our week-long investigation ndash Who Runs Scotland ndash claimed it has revealed deep flaws in our transparency legislation and a heavy reliance on big businesses based outwith Scotland, including those with links to tax havens.Read the full final story here.

title: subscribe-herald-just-2
story: We want to bring you the best The Herald has to offer every day, from our unrivalled news and political coverage to our exclusive investigations.For just pound for two months, you can instantly read columns from your favoritecolumnistsincluding Brian Taylor, Alison Rowat, Mark Smith, and Iain Machiwhirter, and get the latest news and updates straight to your inbox with our tailored newsletters.When you head over to our subscriptions page yoursquoll see three options:Our specialoffer can be found under the ldquoPremium Plus plan under the option ofpoundfor two months, then pound. monthly afterwardsyou decide to stay with us.A subscription will give you access to unrivaled coverage as well as a number of unmissable perks.With that subscription, yoursquoll see % fewer adverts on our websiteand have unlimited access to all our stories, including premium articles.This means you will be able to readThe Heralds online coverage from our award-winning team uninterrupted.As a Herald subscriber, you will also have access to exclusive "Premium" articles. Around one in five of our stories are onlyavailable to people who have signed up for a Herald subscription.These articles are the very best of what we do - written by ourtop writers across a range of specialisms, from politics, to sport, to business, to arts. They could be analysis, comment, insight, interviews, features, or exclusive investigations.We also cannot forget about Voices Live, our section created specically to give our online subscribers exclusive, instant analysis on some of the largest stories in the Scottish news scene each day.As a subscriber, youll instantly have access to our new and improved newsletters on The Herald.You can sign up to all our newsletters here.Every weekday at pm, you can get our brand new evening political newsletter, Unspun, straight to your inbox.It promises readers an exclusive analysis of the day in Scottish politics - and a look at whats coming next.Finally, you will also get access to our enhanced digital package including a news app to keep you up to date on the go and our e-edition of the paper.You can enjoy the digital page-turning edition of The Herald  Herald on Sunday as well as our magazines and special publications.Subscribe to The Herald and dont miss a single word from your favourite columnists and reports by clicking here.

title: scottish-politics-features-covid-sign-newsletters
story: Weve been expanding our newsletter service here at The Herald, and we want to take you through our new and improved offerings.You can subscribe to our newslettersyoure a registered user or a subscriber by heading to our sign up page and selecting your favourites.Every day, were giving you a rundown of who you can expect in our incredible Voices section.We go through the columnists of the day, giving a sneak peek into their musings -
